00030 # A list of types that are treated as linkable.
00031 linkable_types = ['executable', 'shared_library', 'loadable_module']

00033 # A list of sections that contain links to other targets.
00034 dependency_sections = ['dependencies', 'export_dependent_settings']

00036 # base_path_sections is a list of sections defined by GYP that contain
00037 # pathnames.  The generators can provide more keys, the two lists are merged
00038 # into path_sections, but you should call IsPathSection instead of using either
00039 # list directly.
00040 base_path_sections = [
00041   'destination',
00042   'files',
00043   'include_dirs',
00044   'inputs',
00045   'libraries',
00046   'outputs',
00047   'sources',
00048 ]
00049 path_sections = set()
00050 
00051 # These per-process dictionaries are used to cache build file data when loading
00052 # in parallel mode.
00053 per_process_data = {}
00054 per_process_aux_data = {}
00055 
00056 def IsPathSection(section):
00057   # If section ends in one of the '=+?!' characters, it's applied to a section
00058   # without the trailing characters.  '/' is notably absent from this list,
00059   # because there's no way for a regular expression to be treated as a path.
00060   while section[-1:] in '=+?!':
00061     section = section[:-1]
00062 
00063   if section in path_sections:
00064     return True
00065 
00066   # Sections mathing the regexp '_(dir|file|path)s?$' are also
00067   # considered PathSections. Using manual string matching since that
00068   # is much faster than the regexp and this can be called hundreds of
00069   # thousands of times so micro performance matters.
00070   if "_" in section:
00071     tail = section[-6:]
00072     if tail[-1] == 's':
00073       tail = tail[:-1]
00074     if tail[-5:] in ('_file', '_path'):
00075       return True
00076     return tail[-4:] == '_dir'
00077 
00078   return False
00079 
00080 # base_non_configuration_keys is a list of key names that belong in the target
00081 # itself and should not be propagated into its configurations.  It is merged
00082 # with a list that can come from the generator to
00083 # create non_configuration_keys.
00084 base_non_configuration_keys = [
00085   # Sections that must exist inside targets and not configurations.
00086   'actions',
00087   'configurations',
00088   'copies',
00089   'default_configuration',
00090   'dependencies',
00091   'dependencies_original',
00092   'libraries',
00093   'postbuilds',
00094   'product_dir',
00095   'product_extension',
00096   'product_name',
00097   'product_prefix',
00098   'rules',
00099   'run_as',
00100   'sources',
00101   'standalone_static_library',
00102   'suppress_wildcard',
00103   'target_name',
00104   'toolset',
00105   'toolsets',
00106   'type',
00107 
00108   # Sections that can be found inside targets or configurations, but that
00109   # should not be propagated from targets into their configurations.
00110   'variables',
00111 ]
00112 non_configuration_keys = []
00113 
00114 # Keys that do not belong inside a configuration dictionary.
00115 invalid_configuration_keys = [
00116   'actions',
00117   'all_dependent_settings',
00118   'configurations',
00119   'dependencies',
00120   'direct_dependent_settings',
00121   'libraries',
00122   'link_settings',

00124   'standalone_static_library',

00126   'type',

00138 def GetIncludedBuildFiles(build_file_path, aux_data, included=None):
00139   """Return a list of all build files included into build_file_path.
00140 
00141   The returned list will contain build_file_path as well as all other files
00142   that it included, either directly or indirectly.  Note that the list may
00143   contain files that were included into a conditional section that evaluated
00144   to false and was not merged into build_file_path's dict.
00145 
00146   aux_data is a dict containing a key for each build file or included build
00147   file.  Those keys provide access to dicts whose "included" keys contain
00148   lists of all other files included by the build file.
00149 
00150   included should be left at its default None value by external callers.  It
00151   is used for recursion.
00152 
00153   The returned list will not contain any duplicate entries.  Each build file
00154   in the list will be relative to the current directory.
00155   """
00156 
00157   if included == None:
00158     included = []
00159 
00160   if build_file_path in included:
00161     return included
00162 
00163   included.append(build_file_path)
00164 
00165   for included_build_file in aux_data[build_file_path].get('included', []):
00166     GetIncludedBuildFiles(included_build_file, aux_data, included)
00167 
00168   return included

00170 
00171 def CheckedEval(file_contents):
00172   """Return the eval of a gyp file.
00173 
00174   The gyp file is restricted to dictionaries and lists only, and
00175   repeated keys are not allowed.
00176 
00177   Note that this is slower than eval() is.
00178   """
00179 
00180   ast = compiler.parse(file_contents)
00181   assert isinstance(ast, Module)
00182   c1 = ast.getChildren()
00183   assert c1[0] is None
00184   assert isinstance(c1[1], Stmt)
00185   c2 = c1[1].getChildren()
00186   assert isinstance(c2[0], Discard)
00187   c3 = c2[0].getChildren()
00188   assert len(c3) == 1
00189   return CheckNode(c3[0], [])
00190 
00191 
00192 def CheckNode(node, keypath):
00193   if isinstance(node, Dict):
00194     c = node.getChildren()
00195     dict = {}
00196     for n in range(0, len(c), 2):
00197       assert isinstance(c[n], Const)
00198       key = c[n].getChildren()[0]
00199       if key in dict:
00200         raise GypError("Key '" + key + "' repeated at level " +
00201               repr(len(keypath) + 1) + " with key path '" +
00202               '.'.join(keypath) + "'")
00203       kp = list(keypath)  # Make a copy of the list for descending this node.
00204       kp.append(key)
00205       dict[key] = CheckNode(c[n + 1], kp)
00206     return dict
00207   elif isinstance(node, List):
00208     c = node.getChildren()
00209     children = []
00210     for index, child in enumerate(c):
00211       kp = list(keypath)  # Copy list.
00212       kp.append(repr(index))
00213       children.append(CheckNode(child, kp))
00214     return children
00215   elif isinstance(node, Const):
00216     return node.getChildren()[0]
00217   else:
00218     raise TypeError("Unknown AST node at key path '" + '.'.join(keypath) +
00219          "': " + repr(node))
00220

00222 def LoadOneBuildFile(build_file_path, data, aux_data, includes,
00223                      is_target, check):
00224   if build_file_path in data:
00225     return data[build_file_path]
00226 
00227   if os.path.exists(build_file_path):
00228     build_file_contents = open(build_file_path).read()
00229   else:
00230     raise GypError("%s not found (cwd: %s)" % (build_file_path, os.getcwd()))
00231 
00232   build_file_data = None
00233   try:
00234     if check:
00235       build_file_data = CheckedEval(build_file_contents)
00236     else:
00237       build_file_data = eval(build_file_contents, {'__builtins__': None},
00238                              None)
00239   except SyntaxError, e:
00240     e.filename = build_file_path
00241     raise
00242   except Exception, e:
00243     gyp.common.ExceptionAppend(e, 'while reading ' + build_file_path)
00244     raise
00245 
00246   if type(build_file_data) is not dict:
00247     raise GypError("%s does not evaluate to a dictionary." % build_file_path)
00248 
00249   data[build_file_path] = build_file_data
00250   aux_data[build_file_path] = {}
00251 
00252   # Scan for includes and merge them in.
00253   if ('skip_includes' not in build_file_data or
00254       not build_file_data['skip_includes']):
00255     try:
00256       if is_target:
00257         LoadBuildFileIncludesIntoDict(build_file_data, build_file_path, data,
00258                                       aux_data, includes, check)
00259       else:
00260         LoadBuildFileIncludesIntoDict(build_file_data, build_file_path, data,
00261                                       aux_data, None, check)
00262     except Exception, e:
00263       gyp.common.ExceptionAppend(e,
00264                                  'while reading includes of ' + build_file_path)
00265       raise
00266 
00267   return build_file_data
00268 
00269 
00270 def LoadBuildFileIncludesIntoDict(subdict, subdict_path, data, aux_data,
00271                                   includes, check):
00272   includes_list = []
00273   if includes != None:
00274     includes_list.extend(includes)
00275   if 'includes' in subdict:
00276     for include in subdict['includes']:
00277       # "include" is specified relative to subdict_path, so compute the real
00278       # path to include by appending the provided "include" to the directory
00279       # in which subdict_path resides.
00280       relative_include = \
00281           os.path.normpath(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(subdict_path), include))
00282       includes_list.append(relative_include)
00283     # Unhook the includes list, it's no longer needed.
00284     del subdict['includes']
00285 
00286   # Merge in the included files.
00287   for include in includes_list:
00288     if not 'included' in aux_data[subdict_path]:
00289       aux_data[subdict_path]['included'] = []
00290     aux_data[subdict_path]['included'].append(include)
00291 
00292     gyp.DebugOutput(gyp.DEBUG_INCLUDES, "Loading Included File: '%s'", include)
00293 
00294     MergeDicts(subdict,
00295                LoadOneBuildFile(include, data, aux_data, None, False, check),
00296                subdict_path, include)
00297 
00298   # Recurse into subdictionaries.
00299   for k, v in subdict.iteritems():
00300     if type(v) is dict:
00301       LoadBuildFileIncludesIntoDict(v, subdict_path, data, aux_data,
00302                                     None, check)
00303     elif type(v) is list:
00304       LoadBuildFileIncludesIntoList(v, subdict_path, data, aux_data,
00305                                     check)
00306 
00307 
00308 # This recurses into lists so that it can look for dicts.
00309 def LoadBuildFileIncludesIntoList(sublist, sublist_path, data, aux_data, check):
00310   for item in sublist:
00311     if type(item) is dict:
00312       LoadBuildFileIncludesIntoDict(item, sublist_path, data, aux_data,
00313                                     None, check)
00314     elif type(item) is list:
00315       LoadBuildFileIncludesIntoList(item, sublist_path, data, aux_data, check)
00316 
00317 # Processes toolsets in all the targets. This recurses into condition entries
00318 # since they can contain toolsets as well.
00319 def ProcessToolsetsInDict(data):
00320   if 'targets' in data:
00321     target_list = data['targets']
00322     new_target_list = []
00323     for target in target_list:
00324       # If this target already has an explicit 'toolset', and no 'toolsets'
00325       # list, don't modify it further.
00326       if 'toolset' in target and 'toolsets' not in target:
00327         new_target_list.append(target)
00328         continue
00329       if multiple_toolsets:
00330         toolsets = target.get('toolsets', ['target'])
00331       else:
00332         toolsets = ['target']
00333       # Make sure this 'toolsets' definition is only processed once.
00334       if 'toolsets' in target:
00335         del target['toolsets']
00336       if len(toolsets) > 0:
00337         # Optimization: only do copies if more than one toolset is specified.
00338         for build in toolsets[1:]:
00339           new_target = gyp.simple_copy.deepcopy(target)
00340           new_target['toolset'] = build
00341           new_target_list.append(new_target)
00342         target['toolset'] = toolsets[0]
00343         new_target_list.append(target)
00344     data['targets'] = new_target_list
00345   if 'conditions' in data:
00346     for condition in data['conditions']:
00347       if type(condition) is list:
00348         for condition_dict in condition[1:]:
00349           if type(condition_dict) is dict:
00350             ProcessToolsetsInDict(condition_dict)
00351 
00352 
00353 # TODO(mark): I don't love this name.  It just means that it's going to load
00354 # a build file that contains targets and is expected to provide a targets dict
00355 # that contains the targets...
00356 def LoadTargetBuildFile(build_file_path, data, aux_data, variables, includes,
00357                         depth, check, load_dependencies):
00358   # If depth is set, predefine the DEPTH variable to be a relative path from
00359   # this build file's directory to the directory identified by depth.
00360   if depth:
00361     # TODO(dglazkov) The backslash/forward-slash replacement at the end is a
00362     # temporary measure. This should really be addressed by keeping all paths
00363     # in POSIX until actual project generation.
00364     d = gyp.common.RelativePath(depth, os.path.dirname(build_file_path))
00365     if d == '':
00366       variables['DEPTH'] = '.'
00367     else:
00368       variables['DEPTH'] = d.replace('\\', '/')
00369 
00370   # The 'target_build_files' key is only set when loading target build files in
00371   # the non-parallel code path, where LoadTargetBuildFile is called
00372   # recursively.  In the parallel code path, we don't need to check whether the
00373   # |build_file_path| has already been loaded, because the 'scheduled' set in
00374   # ParallelState guarantees that we never load the same |build_file_path|
00375   # twice.
00376   if 'target_build_files' in data:
00377     if build_file_path in data['target_build_files']:
00378       # Already loaded.
00379       return False
00380     data['target_build_files'].add(build_file_path)
00381 
00382   gyp.DebugOutput(gyp.DEBUG_INCLUDES,
00383                   "Loading Target Build File '%s'", build_file_path)
00384 
00385   build_file_data = LoadOneBuildFile(build_file_path, data, aux_data,
00386                                      includes, True, check)
00387 
00388   # Store DEPTH for later use in generators.
00389   build_file_data['_DEPTH'] = depth
00390 
00391   # Set up the included_files key indicating which .gyp files contributed to
00392   # this target dict.
00393   if 'included_files' in build_file_data:
00394     raise GypError(build_file_path + ' must not contain included_files key')
00395 
00396   included = GetIncludedBuildFiles(build_file_path, aux_data)
00397   build_file_data['included_files'] = []
00398   for included_file in included:
00399     # included_file is relative to the current directory, but it needs to
00400     # be made relative to build_file_path's directory.
00401     included_relative = \
00402         gyp.common.RelativePath(included_file,
00403                                 os.path.dirname(build_file_path))
00404     build_file_data['included_files'].append(included_relative)
00405 
00406   # Do a first round of toolsets expansion so that conditions can be defined
00407   # per toolset.
00408   ProcessToolsetsInDict(build_file_data)
00409 
00410   # Apply "pre"/"early" variable expansions and condition evaluations.
00411   ProcessVariablesAndConditionsInDict(
00412       build_file_data, PHASE_EARLY, variables, build_file_path)
00413 
00414   # Since some toolsets might have been defined conditionally, perform
00415   # a second round of toolsets expansion now.
00416   ProcessToolsetsInDict(build_file_data)
00417 
00418   # Look at each project's target_defaults dict, and merge settings into
00419   # targets.
00420   if 'target_defaults' in build_file_data:
00421     if 'targets' not in build_file_data:
00422       raise GypError("Unable to find targets in build file %s" %
00423                      build_file_path)
00424 
00425     index = 0
00426     while index < len(build_file_data['targets']):
00427       # This procedure needs to give the impression that target_defaults is
00428       # used as defaults, and the individual targets inherit from that.
00429       # The individual targets need to be merged into the defaults.  Make
00430       # a deep copy of the defaults for each target, merge the target dict
00431       # as found in the input file into that copy, and then hook up the
00432       # copy with the target-specific data merged into it as the replacement
00433       # target dict.
00434       old_target_dict = build_file_data['targets'][index]
00435       new_target_dict = gyp.simple_copy.deepcopy(
00436         build_file_data['target_defaults'])
00437       MergeDicts(new_target_dict, old_target_dict,
00438                  build_file_path, build_file_path)
00439       build_file_data['targets'][index] = new_target_dict
00440       index += 1
00441 
00442     # No longer needed.
00443     del build_file_data['target_defaults']
00444 
00445   # Look for dependencies.  This means that dependency resolution occurs
00446   # after "pre" conditionals and variable expansion, but before "post" -
00447   # in other words, you can't put a "dependencies" section inside a "post"
00448   # conditional within a target.
00449 
00450   dependencies = []
00451   if 'targets' in build_file_data:
00452     for target_dict in build_file_data['targets']:
00453       if 'dependencies' not in target_dict:
00454         continue
00455       for dependency in target_dict['dependencies']:
00456         dependencies.append(
00457             gyp.common.ResolveTarget(build_file_path, dependency, None)[0])
00458 
00459   if load_dependencies:
00460     for dependency in dependencies:
00461       try:
00462         LoadTargetBuildFile(dependency, data, aux_data, variables,
00463                             includes, depth, check, load_dependencies)
00464       except Exception, e:
00465         gyp.common.ExceptionAppend(
00466           e, 'while loading dependencies of %s' % build_file_path)
00467         raise
00468   else:
00469     return (build_file_path, dependencies)
00470 
00471 def CallLoadTargetBuildFile(global_flags,
00472                             build_file_path, variables,
00473                             includes, depth, check,
00474                             generator_input_info):
00475   """Wrapper around LoadTargetBuildFile for parallel processing.
00476 
00477      This wrapper is used when LoadTargetBuildFile is executed in
00478      a worker process.
00479   """
00480 
00481   try:
00482     signal.signal(signal.SIGINT, signal.SIG_IGN)
00483 
00484     # Apply globals so that the worker process behaves the same.
00485     for key, value in global_flags.iteritems():
00486       globals()[key] = value
00487 
00488     SetGeneratorGlobals(generator_input_info)
00489     result = LoadTargetBuildFile(build_file_path, per_process_data,
00490                                  per_process_aux_data, variables,
00491                                  includes, depth, check, False)
00492     if not result:
00493       return result
00494 
00495     (build_file_path, dependencies) = result
00496 
00497     # We can safely pop the build_file_data from per_process_data because it
00498     # will never be referenced by this process again, so we don't need to keep
00499     # it in the cache.
00500     build_file_data = per_process_data.pop(build_file_path)
00501 
00502     # This gets serialized and sent back to the main process via a pipe.
00503     # It's handled in LoadTargetBuildFileCallback.
00504     return (build_file_path,
00505             build_file_data,
00506             dependencies)
00507   except GypError, e:
00508     sys.stderr.write("gyp: %s\n" % e)
00509     return None
00510   except Exception, e:
00511     print >>sys.stderr, 'Exception:', e
00512     print >>sys.stderr, traceback.format_exc()
00513     return None
00514

00516 class ParallelProcessingError(Exception):
00517   pass

00520 class ParallelState(object):
00521   """Class to keep track of state when processing input files in parallel.
00522 
00523   If build files are loaded in parallel, use this to keep track of
00524   state during farming out and processing parallel jobs. It's stored
00525   in a global so that the callback function can have access to it.
00526   """
00527 
00528   def __init__(self):
00529     # The multiprocessing pool.
00530     self.pool = None
00531     # The condition variable used to protect this object and notify
00532     # the main loop when there might be more data to process.
00533     self.condition = None
00534     # The "data" dict that was passed to LoadTargetBuildFileParallel
00535     self.data = None
00536     # The number of parallel calls outstanding; decremented when a response
00537     # was received.
00538     self.pending = 0
00539     # The set of all build files that have been scheduled, so we don't
00540     # schedule the same one twice.
00541     self.scheduled = set()
00542     # A list of dependency build file paths that haven't been scheduled yet.
00543     self.dependencies = []
00544     # Flag to indicate if there was an error in a child process.
00545     self.error = False
00546 
00547   def LoadTargetBuildFileCallback(self, result):
00548     """Handle the results of running LoadTargetBuildFile in another process.
00549     """
00550     self.condition.acquire()
00551     if not result:
00552       self.error = True
00553       self.condition.notify()
00554       self.condition.release()
00555       return
00556     (build_file_path0, build_file_data0, dependencies0) = result
00557     self.data[build_file_path0] = build_file_data0
00558     self.data['target_build_files'].add(build_file_path0)
00559     for new_dependency in dependencies0:
00560       if new_dependency not in self.scheduled:
00561         self.scheduled.add(new_dependency)
00562         self.dependencies.append(new_dependency)
00563     self.pending -= 1
00564     self.condition.notify()
00565     self.condition.release()
00566 
00567 
00568 def LoadTargetBuildFilesParallel(build_files, data, variables, includes, depth,
00569                                  check, generator_input_info):
00570   parallel_state = ParallelState()
00571   parallel_state.condition = threading.Condition()
00572   # Make copies of the build_files argument that we can modify while working.
00573   parallel_state.dependencies = list(build_files)
00574   parallel_state.scheduled = set(build_files)
00575   parallel_state.pending = 0
00576   parallel_state.data = data
00577 
00578   try:
00579     parallel_state.condition.acquire()
00580     while parallel_state.dependencies or parallel_state.pending:
00581       if parallel_state.error:
00582         break
00583       if not parallel_state.dependencies:
00584         parallel_state.condition.wait()
00585         continue
00586 
00587       dependency = parallel_state.dependencies.pop()
00588 
00589       parallel_state.pending += 1
00590       global_flags = {
00591         'path_sections': globals()['path_sections'],
00592         'non_configuration_keys': globals()['non_configuration_keys'],
00593         'multiple_toolsets': globals()['multiple_toolsets']}
00594 
00595       if not parallel_state.pool:
00596         parallel_state.pool = multiprocessing.Pool(multiprocessing.cpu_count())
00597       parallel_state.pool.apply_async(
00598           CallLoadTargetBuildFile,
00599           args = (global_flags, dependency,
00600                   variables, includes, depth, check, generator_input_info),
00601           callback = parallel_state.LoadTargetBuildFileCallback)
00602   except KeyboardInterrupt, e:
00603     parallel_state.pool.terminate()
00604     raise e
00605 
00606   parallel_state.condition.release()
00607 
00608   parallel_state.pool.close()
00609   parallel_state.pool.join()
00610   parallel_state.pool = None
00611 
00612   if parallel_state.error:
00613     sys.exit(1)
00614 
00615 # Look for the bracket that matches the first bracket seen in a
00616 # string, and return the start and end as a tuple.  For example, if
00617 # the input is something like "<(foo <(bar)) blah", then it would
00618 # return (1, 13), indicating the entire string except for the leading
00619 # "<" and trailing " blah".
00620 LBRACKETS= set('{[(')
00621 BRACKETS = {'}': '{', ']': '[', ')': '('}
00622 def FindEnclosingBracketGroup(input_str):
00623   stack = []
00624   start = -1
00625   for index, char in enumerate(input_str):
00626     if char in LBRACKETS:
00627       stack.append(char)
00628       if start == -1:
00629         start = index
00630     elif char in BRACKETS:
00631       if not stack:
00632         return (-1, -1)
00633       if stack.pop() != BRACKETS[char]:
00634         return (-1, -1)
00635       if not stack:
00636         return (start, index + 1)
00637   return (-1, -1)
00638 
00639 
00640 def IsStrCanonicalInt(string):
00641   """Returns True if |string| is in its canonical integer form.
00642 
00643   The canonical form is such that str(int(string)) == string.
00644   """
00645   if type(string) is str:
00646     # This function is called a lot so for maximum performance, avoid
00647     # involving regexps which would otherwise make the code much
00648     # shorter. Regexps would need twice the time of this function.
00649     if string:
00650       if string == "0":
00651         return True
00652       if string[0] == "-":
00653         string = string[1:]
00654         if not string:
00655           return False
00656       if '1' <= string[0] <= '9':
00657         return string.isdigit()
00658 
00659   return False
00660 
00661 
00662 # This matches things like "<(asdf)", "<!(cmd)", "<!@(cmd)", "<|(list)",
00663 # "<!interpreter(arguments)", "<([list])", and even "<([)" and "<(<())".
00664 # In the last case, the inner "<()" is captured in match['content'].
00665 early_variable_re = re.compile(
00666     r'(?P<replace>(?P<type><(?:(?:!?@?)|\|)?)'
00667     r'(?P<command_string>[-a-zA-Z0-9_.]+)?'
00668     r'\((?P<is_array>\s*\[?)'
00669     r'(?P<content>.*?)(\]?)\))')
00670 
00671 # This matches the same as early_variable_re, but with '>' instead of '<'.
00672 late_variable_re = re.compile(
00673     r'(?P<replace>(?P<type>>(?:(?:!?@?)|\|)?)'
00674     r'(?P<command_string>[-a-zA-Z0-9_.]+)?'
00675     r'\((?P<is_array>\s*\[?)'
00676     r'(?P<content>.*?)(\]?)\))')
00677 
00678 # This matches the same as early_variable_re, but with '^' instead of '<'.
00679 latelate_variable_re = re.compile(
00680     r'(?P<replace>(?P<type>[\^](?:(?:!?@?)|\|)?)'
00681     r'(?P<command_string>[-a-zA-Z0-9_.]+)?'
00682     r'\((?P<is_array>\s*\[?)'
00683     r'(?P<content>.*?)(\]?)\))')
00684 
00685 # Global cache of results from running commands so they don't have to be run
00686 # more then once.
00687 cached_command_results = {}
00688 
00689 
00690 def FixupPlatformCommand(cmd):
00691   if sys.platform == 'win32':
00692     if type(cmd) is list:
00693       cmd = [re.sub('^cat ', 'type ', cmd[0])] + cmd[1:]
00694     else:
00695       cmd = re.sub('^cat ', 'type ', cmd)
00696   return cmd
00697 
00698 
00699 PHASE_EARLY = 0
00700 PHASE_LATE = 1
00701 PHASE_LATELATE = 2
00702 
00703 
00704 def ExpandVariables(input, phase, variables, build_file):
00705   # Look for the pattern that gets expanded into variables
00706   if phase == PHASE_EARLY:
00707     variable_re = early_variable_re
00708     expansion_symbol = '<'
00709   elif phase == PHASE_LATE:
00710     variable_re = late_variable_re
00711     expansion_symbol = '>'
00712   elif phase == PHASE_LATELATE:
00713     variable_re = latelate_variable_re
00714     expansion_symbol = '^'
00715   else:
00716     assert False
00717 
00718   input_str = str(input)
00719   if IsStrCanonicalInt(input_str):
00720     return int(input_str)
00721 
00722   # Do a quick scan to determine if an expensive regex search is warranted.
00723   if expansion_symbol not in input_str:
00724     return input_str
00725 
00726   # Get the entire list of matches as a list of MatchObject instances.
00727   # (using findall here would return strings instead of MatchObjects).
00728   matches = list(variable_re.finditer(input_str))
00729   if not matches:
00730     return input_str
00731 
00732   output = input_str
00733   # Reverse the list of matches so that replacements are done right-to-left.
00734   # That ensures that earlier replacements won't mess up the string in a
00735   # way that causes later calls to find the earlier substituted text instead
00736   # of what's intended for replacement.
00737   matches.reverse()
00738   for match_group in matches:
00739     match = match_group.groupdict()
00740     gyp.DebugOutput(gyp.DEBUG_VARIABLES, "Matches: %r", match)
00741     # match['replace'] is the substring to look for, match['type']
00742     # is the character code for the replacement type (< > <! >! <| >| <@
00743     # >@ <!@ >!@), match['is_array'] contains a '[' for command
00744     # arrays, and match['content'] is the name of the variable (< >)
00745     # or command to run (<! >!). match['command_string'] is an optional
00746     # command string. Currently, only 'pymod_do_main' is supported.
00747 
00748     # run_command is true if a ! variant is used.
00749     run_command = '!' in match['type']
00750     command_string = match['command_string']
00751 
00752     # file_list is true if a | variant is used.
00753     file_list = '|' in match['type']
00754 
00755     # Capture these now so we can adjust them later.
00756     replace_start = match_group.start('replace')
00757     replace_end = match_group.end('replace')
00758 
00759     # Find the ending paren, and re-evaluate the contained string.
00760     (c_start, c_end) = FindEnclosingBracketGroup(input_str[replace_start:])
00761 
00762     # Adjust the replacement range to match the entire command
00763     # found by FindEnclosingBracketGroup (since the variable_re
00764     # probably doesn't match the entire command if it contained
00765     # nested variables).
00766     replace_end = replace_start + c_end
00767 
00768     # Find the "real" replacement, matching the appropriate closing
00769     # paren, and adjust the replacement start and end.
00770     replacement = input_str[replace_start:replace_end]
00771 
00772     # Figure out what the contents of the variable parens are.
00773     contents_start = replace_start + c_start + 1
00774     contents_end = replace_end - 1
00775     contents = input_str[contents_start:contents_end]
00776 
00777     # Do filter substitution now for <|().
00778     # Admittedly, this is different than the evaluation order in other
00779     # contexts. However, since filtration has no chance to run on <|(),
00780     # this seems like the only obvious way to give them access to filters.
00781     if file_list:
00782       processed_variables = gyp.simple_copy.deepcopy(variables)
00783       ProcessListFiltersInDict(contents, processed_variables)
00784       # Recurse to expand variables in the contents
00785       contents = ExpandVariables(contents, phase,
00786                                  processed_variables, build_file)
00787     else:
00788       # Recurse to expand variables in the contents
00789       contents = ExpandVariables(contents, phase, variables, build_file)
00790 
00791     # Strip off leading/trailing whitespace so that variable matches are
00792     # simpler below (and because they are rarely needed).
00793     contents = contents.strip()
00794 
00795     # expand_to_list is true if an @ variant is used.  In that case,
00796     # the expansion should result in a list.  Note that the caller
00797     # is to be expecting a list in return, and not all callers do
00798     # because not all are working in list context.  Also, for list
00799     # expansions, there can be no other text besides the variable
00800     # expansion in the input string.
00801     expand_to_list = '@' in match['type'] and input_str == replacement
00802 
00803     if run_command or file_list:
00804       # Find the build file's directory, so commands can be run or file lists
00805       # generated relative to it.
00806       build_file_dir = os.path.dirname(build_file)
00807       if build_file_dir == '' and not file_list:
00808         # If build_file is just a leaf filename indicating a file in the
00809         # current directory, build_file_dir might be an empty string.  Set
00810         # it to None to signal to subprocess.Popen that it should run the
00811         # command in the current directory.
00812         build_file_dir = None
00813 
00814     # Support <|(listfile.txt ...) which generates a file
00815     # containing items from a gyp list, generated at gyp time.
00816     # This works around actions/rules which have more inputs than will
00817     # fit on the command line.
00818     if file_list:
00819       if type(contents) is list:
00820         contents_list = contents
00821       else:
00822         contents_list = contents.split(' ')
00823       replacement = contents_list[0]
00824       if os.path.isabs(replacement):
00825         raise GypError('| cannot handle absolute paths, got "%s"' % replacement)
00826 
00827       if not generator_filelist_paths:
00828         path = os.path.join(build_file_dir, replacement)
00829       else:
00830         if os.path.isabs(build_file_dir):
00831           toplevel = generator_filelist_paths['toplevel']
00832           rel_build_file_dir = gyp.common.RelativePath(build_file_dir, toplevel)
00833         else:
00834           rel_build_file_dir = build_file_dir
00835         qualified_out_dir = generator_filelist_paths['qualified_out_dir']
00836         path = os.path.join(qualified_out_dir, rel_build_file_dir, replacement)
00837         gyp.common.EnsureDirExists(path)
00838 
00839       replacement = gyp.common.RelativePath(path, build_file_dir)
00840       f = gyp.common.WriteOnDiff(path)
00841       for i in contents_list[1:]:
00842         f.write('%s\n' % i)
00843       f.close()
00844 
00845     elif run_command:
00846       use_shell = True
00847       if match['is_array']:
00848         contents = eval(contents)
00849         use_shell = False
00850 
00851       # Check for a cached value to avoid executing commands, or generating
00852       # file lists more than once. The cache key contains the command to be
00853       # run as well as the directory to run it from, to account for commands
00854       # that depend on their current directory.
00855       # TODO(http://code.google.com/p/gyp/issues/detail?id=111): In theory,
00856       # someone could author a set of GYP files where each time the command
00857       # is invoked it produces different output by design. When the need
00858       # arises, the syntax should be extended to support no caching off a
00859       # command's output so it is run every time.
00860       cache_key = (str(contents), build_file_dir)
00861       cached_value = cached_command_results.get(cache_key, None)
00862       if cached_value is None:
00863         gyp.DebugOutput(gyp.DEBUG_VARIABLES,
00864                         "Executing command '%s' in directory '%s'",
00865                         contents, build_file_dir)
00866 
00867         replacement = ''
00868 
00869         if command_string == 'pymod_do_main':
00870           # <!pymod_do_main(modulename param eters) loads |modulename| as a
00871           # python module and then calls that module's DoMain() function,
00872           # passing ["param", "eters"] as a single list argument. For modules
00873           # that don't load quickly, this can be faster than
00874           # <!(python modulename param eters). Do this in |build_file_dir|.
00875           oldwd = os.getcwd()  # Python doesn't like os.open('.'): no fchdir.
00876           if build_file_dir:  # build_file_dir may be None (see above).
00877             os.chdir(build_file_dir)
00878           try:
00879 
00880             parsed_contents = shlex.split(contents)
00881             try:
00882               py_module = __import__(parsed_contents[0])
00883             except ImportError as e:
00884               raise GypError("Error importing pymod_do_main"
00885                              "module (%s): %s" % (parsed_contents[0], e))
00886             replacement = str(py_module.DoMain(parsed_contents[1:])).rstrip()
00887           finally:
00888             os.chdir(oldwd)
00889           assert replacement != None
00890         elif command_string:
00891           raise GypError("Unknown command string '%s' in '%s'." %
00892                          (command_string, contents))
00893         else:
00894           # Fix up command with platform specific workarounds.
00895           contents = FixupPlatformCommand(contents)
00896           p = subprocess.Popen(contents, shell=use_shell,
00897                                stdout=subprocess.PIPE,
00898                                stderr=subprocess.PIPE,
00899                                stdin=subprocess.PIPE,
00900                                cwd=build_file_dir)
00901 
00902           p_stdout, p_stderr = p.communicate('')
00903 
00904           if p.wait() != 0 or p_stderr:
00905             sys.stderr.write(p_stderr)
00906             # Simulate check_call behavior, since check_call only exists
00907             # in python 2.5 and later.
00908             raise GypError("Call to '%s' returned exit status %d." %
00909                            (contents, p.returncode))
00910           replacement = p_stdout.rstrip()
00911 
00912         cached_command_results[cache_key] = replacement
00913       else:
00914         gyp.DebugOutput(gyp.DEBUG_VARIABLES,
00915                         "Had cache value for command '%s' in directory '%s'",
00916                         contents,build_file_dir)
00917         replacement = cached_value
00918 
00919     else:
00920       if not contents in variables:
00921         if contents[-1] in ['!', '/']:
00922           # In order to allow cross-compiles (nacl) to happen more naturally,
00923           # we will allow references to >(sources/) etc. to resolve to
00924           # and empty list if undefined. This allows actions to:
00925           # 'action!': [
00926           #   '>@(_sources!)',
00927           # ],
00928           # 'action/': [
00929           #   '>@(_sources/)',
00930           # ],
00931           replacement = []
00932         else:
00933           raise GypError('Undefined variable ' + contents +
00934                          ' in ' + build_file)
00935       else:
00936         replacement = variables[contents]
00937 
00938     if type(replacement) is list:
00939       for item in replacement:
00940         if not contents[-1] == '/' and type(item) not in (str, int):
00941           raise GypError('Variable ' + contents +
00942                          ' must expand to a string or list of strings; ' +
00943                          'list contains a ' +
00944                          item.__class__.__name__)
00945       # Run through the list and handle variable expansions in it.  Since
00946       # the list is guaranteed not to contain dicts, this won't do anything
00947       # with conditions sections.
00948       ProcessVariablesAndConditionsInList(replacement, phase, variables,
00949                                           build_file)
00950     elif type(replacement) not in (str, int):
00951           raise GypError('Variable ' + contents +
00952                          ' must expand to a string or list of strings; ' +
00953                          'found a ' + replacement.__class__.__name__)
00954 
00955     if expand_to_list:
00956       # Expanding in list context.  It's guaranteed that there's only one
00957       # replacement to do in |input_str| and that it's this replacement.  See
00958       # above.
00959       if type(replacement) is list:
00960         # If it's already a list, make a copy.
00961         output = replacement[:]
00962       else:
00963         # Split it the same way sh would split arguments.
00964         output = shlex.split(str(replacement))
00965     else:
00966       # Expanding in string context.
00967       encoded_replacement = ''
00968       if type(replacement) is list:
00969         # When expanding a list into string context, turn the list items
00970         # into a string in a way that will work with a subprocess call.
00971         #
00972         # TODO(mark): This isn't completely correct.  This should
00973         # call a generator-provided function that observes the
00974         # proper list-to-argument quoting rules on a specific
00975         # platform instead of just calling the POSIX encoding
00976         # routine.
00977         encoded_replacement = gyp.common.EncodePOSIXShellList(replacement)
00978       else:
00979         encoded_replacement = replacement
00980 
00981       output = output[:replace_start] + str(encoded_replacement) + \
00982                output[replace_end:]
00983     # Prepare for the next match iteration.
00984     input_str = output
00985 
00986   if output == input:
00987     gyp.DebugOutput(gyp.DEBUG_VARIABLES,
00988                     "Found only identity matches on %r, avoiding infinite "
00989                     "recursion.",
00990                     output)
00991   else:
00992     # Look for more matches now that we've replaced some, to deal with
00993     # expanding local variables (variables defined in the same
00994     # variables block as this one).
00995     gyp.DebugOutput(gyp.DEBUG_VARIABLES, "Found output %r, recursing.", output)
00996     if type(output) is list:
00997       if output and type(output[0]) is list:
00998         # Leave output alone if it's a list of lists.
00999         # We don't want such lists to be stringified.
01000         pass
01001       else:
01002         new_output = []
01003         for item in output:
01004           new_output.append(
01005               ExpandVariables(item, phase, variables, build_file))
01006         output = new_output
01007     else:
01008       output = ExpandVariables(output, phase, variables, build_file)
01009 
01010   # Convert all strings that are canonically-represented integers into integers.
01011   if type(output) is list:
01012     for index in xrange(0, len(output)):
01013       if IsStrCanonicalInt(output[index]):
01014         output[index] = int(output[index])
01015   elif IsStrCanonicalInt(output):
01016     output = int(output)
01017 
01018   return output
01019 
01020 # The same condition is often evaluated over and over again so it
01021 # makes sense to cache as much as possible between evaluations.
01022 cached_conditions_asts = {}
01023 
01024 def EvalCondition(condition, conditions_key, phase, variables, build_file):
01025   """Returns the dict that should be used or None if the result was
01026   that nothing should be used."""
01027   if type(condition) is not list:
01028     raise GypError(conditions_key + ' must be a list')
01029   if len(condition) < 2:
01030     # It's possible that condition[0] won't work in which case this
01031     # attempt will raise its own IndexError.  That's probably fine.
01032     raise GypError(conditions_key + ' ' + condition[0] +
01033                    ' must be at least length 2, not ' + str(len(condition)))
01034 
01035   i = 0
01036   result = None
01037   while i < len(condition):
01038     cond_expr = condition[i]
01039     true_dict = condition[i + 1]
01040     if type(true_dict) is not dict:
01041       raise GypError('{} {} must be followed by a dictionary, not {}'.format(
01042         conditions_key, cond_expr, type(true_dict)))
01043     if len(condition) > i + 2 and type(condition[i + 2]) is dict:
01044       false_dict = condition[i + 2]
01045       i = i + 3
01046       if i != len(condition):
01047         raise GypError('{} {} has {} unexpected trailing items'.format(
01048           conditions_key, cond_expr, len(condition) - i))
01049     else:
01050       false_dict = None
01051       i = i + 2
01052     if result == None:
01053       result = EvalSingleCondition(
01054           cond_expr, true_dict, false_dict, phase, variables, build_file)
01055 
01056   return result
01057 
01058 
01059 def EvalSingleCondition(
01060     cond_expr, true_dict, false_dict, phase, variables, build_file):
01061   """Returns true_dict if cond_expr evaluates to true, and false_dict
01062   otherwise."""
01063   # Do expansions on the condition itself.  Since the conditon can naturally
01064   # contain variable references without needing to resort to GYP expansion
01065   # syntax, this is of dubious value for variables, but someone might want to
01066   # use a command expansion directly inside a condition.
01067   cond_expr_expanded = ExpandVariables(cond_expr, phase, variables,
01068                                        build_file)
01069   if type(cond_expr_expanded) not in (str, int):
01070     raise ValueError(
01071           'Variable expansion in this context permits str and int ' + \
01072             'only, found ' + cond_expr_expanded.__class__.__name__)
01073 
01074   try:
01075     if cond_expr_expanded in cached_conditions_asts:
01076       ast_code = cached_conditions_asts[cond_expr_expanded]
01077     else:
01078       ast_code = compile(cond_expr_expanded, '<string>', 'eval')
01079       cached_conditions_asts[cond_expr_expanded] = ast_code
01080     if eval(ast_code, {'__builtins__': None}, variables):
01081       return true_dict
01082     return false_dict
01083   except SyntaxError, e:
01084     syntax_error = SyntaxError('%s while evaluating condition \'%s\' in %s '
01085                                'at character %d.' %
01086                                (str(e.args[0]), e.text, build_file, e.offset),
01087                                e.filename, e.lineno, e.offset, e.text)
01088     raise syntax_error
01089   except NameError, e:
01090     gyp.common.ExceptionAppend(e, 'while evaluating condition \'%s\' in %s' %
01091                                (cond_expr_expanded, build_file))
01092     raise GypError(e)
01093 
01094 
01095 def ProcessConditionsInDict(the_dict, phase, variables, build_file):
01096   # Process a 'conditions' or 'target_conditions' section in the_dict,
01097   # depending on phase.
01098   # early -> conditions
01099   # late -> target_conditions
01100   # latelate -> no conditions
01101   #
01102   # Each item in a conditions list consists of cond_expr, a string expression
01103   # evaluated as the condition, and true_dict, a dict that will be merged into
01104   # the_dict if cond_expr evaluates to true.  Optionally, a third item,
01105   # false_dict, may be present.  false_dict is merged into the_dict if
01106   # cond_expr evaluates to false.
01107   #
01108   # Any dict merged into the_dict will be recursively processed for nested
01109   # conditionals and other expansions, also according to phase, immediately
01110   # prior to being merged.
01111 
01112   if phase == PHASE_EARLY:
01113     conditions_key = 'conditions'
01114   elif phase == PHASE_LATE:
01115     conditions_key = 'target_conditions'
01116   elif phase == PHASE_LATELATE:
01117     return
01118   else:
01119     assert False
01120 
01121   if not conditions_key in the_dict:
01122     return
01123 
01124   conditions_list = the_dict[conditions_key]
01125   # Unhook the conditions list, it's no longer needed.
01126   del the_dict[conditions_key]
01127 
01128   for condition in conditions_list:
01129     merge_dict = EvalCondition(condition, conditions_key, phase, variables,
01130                                build_file)
01131 
01132     if merge_dict != None:
01133       # Expand variables and nested conditinals in the merge_dict before
01134       # merging it.
01135       ProcessVariablesAndConditionsInDict(merge_dict, phase,
01136                                           variables, build_file)
01137 
01138       MergeDicts(the_dict, merge_dict, build_file, build_file)
01139 
01140 
01141 def LoadAutomaticVariablesFromDict(variables, the_dict):
01142   # Any keys with plain string values in the_dict become automatic variables.
01143   # The variable name is the key name with a "_" character prepended.
01144   for key, value in the_dict.iteritems():
01145     if type(value) in (str, int, list):
01146       variables['_' + key] = value
01147 
01148 
01149 def LoadVariablesFromVariablesDict(variables, the_dict, the_dict_key):
01150   # Any keys in the_dict's "variables" dict, if it has one, becomes a
01151   # variable.  The variable name is the key name in the "variables" dict.
01152   # Variables that end with the % character are set only if they are unset in
01153   # the variables dict.  the_dict_key is the name of the key that accesses
01154   # the_dict in the_dict's parent dict.  If the_dict's parent is not a dict
01155   # (it could be a list or it could be parentless because it is a root dict),
01156   # the_dict_key will be None.
01157   for key, value in the_dict.get('variables', {}).iteritems():
01158     if type(value) not in (str, int, list):
01159       continue
01160 
01161     if key.endswith('%'):
01162       variable_name = key[:-1]
01163       if variable_name in variables:
01164         # If the variable is already set, don't set it.
01165         continue
01166       if the_dict_key is 'variables' and variable_name in the_dict:
01167         # If the variable is set without a % in the_dict, and the_dict is a
01168         # variables dict (making |variables| a varaibles sub-dict of a
01169         # variables dict), use the_dict's definition.
01170         value = the_dict[variable_name]
01171     else:
01172       variable_name = key
01173 
01174     variables[variable_name] = value
01175 
01176 
01177 def ProcessVariablesAndConditionsInDict(the_dict, phase, variables_in,
01178                                         build_file, the_dict_key=None):
01179   """Handle all variable and command expansion and conditional evaluation.
01180 
01181   This function is the public entry point for all variable expansions and
01182   conditional evaluations.  The variables_in dictionary will not be modified
01183   by this function.
01184   """
01185 
01186   # Make a copy of the variables_in dict that can be modified during the
01187   # loading of automatics and the loading of the variables dict.
01188   variables = variables_in.copy()
01189   LoadAutomaticVariablesFromDict(variables, the_dict)
01190 
01191   if 'variables' in the_dict:
01192     # Make sure all the local variables are added to the variables
01193     # list before we process them so that you can reference one
01194     # variable from another.  They will be fully expanded by recursion
01195     # in ExpandVariables.
01196     for key, value in the_dict['variables'].iteritems():
01197       variables[key] = value
01198 
01199     # Handle the associated variables dict first, so that any variable
01200     # references within can be resolved prior to using them as variables.
01201     # Pass a copy of the variables dict to avoid having it be tainted.
01202     # Otherwise, it would have extra automatics added for everything that
01203     # should just be an ordinary variable in this scope.
01204     ProcessVariablesAndConditionsInDict(the_dict['variables'], phase,
01205                                         variables, build_file, 'variables')
01206 
01207   LoadVariablesFromVariablesDict(variables, the_dict, the_dict_key)
01208 
01209   for key, value in the_dict.iteritems():
01210     # Skip "variables", which was already processed if present.
01211     if key != 'variables' and type(value) is str:
01212       expanded = ExpandVariables(value, phase, variables, build_file)
01213       if type(expanded) not in (str, int):
01214         raise ValueError(
01215               'Variable expansion in this context permits str and int ' + \
01216               'only, found ' + expanded.__class__.__name__ + ' for ' + key)
01217       the_dict[key] = expanded
01218 
01219   # Variable expansion may have resulted in changes to automatics.  Reload.
01220   # TODO(mark): Optimization: only reload if no changes were made.
01221   variables = variables_in.copy()
01222   LoadAutomaticVariablesFromDict(variables, the_dict)
01223   LoadVariablesFromVariablesDict(variables, the_dict, the_dict_key)
01224 
01225   # Process conditions in this dict.  This is done after variable expansion
01226   # so that conditions may take advantage of expanded variables.  For example,
01227   # if the_dict contains:
01228   #   {'type':       '<(library_type)',
01229   #    'conditions': [['_type=="static_library"', { ... }]]},
01230   # _type, as used in the condition, will only be set to the value of
01231   # library_type if variable expansion is performed before condition
01232   # processing.  However, condition processing should occur prior to recursion
01233   # so that variables (both automatic and "variables" dict type) may be
01234   # adjusted by conditions sections, merged into the_dict, and have the
01235   # intended impact on contained dicts.
01236   #
01237   # This arrangement means that a "conditions" section containing a "variables"
01238   # section will only have those variables effective in subdicts, not in
01239   # the_dict.  The workaround is to put a "conditions" section within a
01240   # "variables" section.  For example:
01241   #   {'conditions': [['os=="mac"', {'variables': {'define': 'IS_MAC'}}]],
01242   #    'defines':    ['<(define)'],
01243   #    'my_subdict': {'defines': ['<(define)']}},
01244   # will not result in "IS_MAC" being appended to the "defines" list in the
01245   # current scope but would result in it being appended to the "defines" list
01246   # within "my_subdict".  By comparison:
01247   #   {'variables': {'conditions': [['os=="mac"', {'define': 'IS_MAC'}]]},
01248   #    'defines':    ['<(define)'],
01249   #    'my_subdict': {'defines': ['<(define)']}},
01250   # will append "IS_MAC" to both "defines" lists.
01251 
01252   # Evaluate conditions sections, allowing variable expansions within them
01253   # as well as nested conditionals.  This will process a 'conditions' or
01254   # 'target_conditions' section, perform appropriate merging and recursive
01255   # conditional and variable processing, and then remove the conditions section
01256   # from the_dict if it is present.
01257   ProcessConditionsInDict(the_dict, phase, variables, build_file)
01258 
01259   # Conditional processing may have resulted in changes to automatics or the
01260   # variables dict.  Reload.
01261   variables = variables_in.copy()
01262   LoadAutomaticVariablesFromDict(variables, the_dict)
01263   LoadVariablesFromVariablesDict(variables, the_dict, the_dict_key)
01264 
01265   # Recurse into child dicts, or process child lists which may result in
01266   # further recursion into descendant dicts.
01267   for key, value in the_dict.iteritems():
01268     # Skip "variables" and string values, which were already processed if
01269     # present.
01270     if key == 'variables' or type(value) is str:
01271       continue
01272     if type(value) is dict:
01273       # Pass a copy of the variables dict so that subdicts can't influence
01274       # parents.
01275       ProcessVariablesAndConditionsInDict(value, phase, variables,
01276                                           build_file, key)
01277     elif type(value) is list:
01278       # The list itself can't influence the variables dict, and
01279       # ProcessVariablesAndConditionsInList will make copies of the variables
01280       # dict if it needs to pass it to something that can influence it.  No
01281       # copy is necessary here.
01282       ProcessVariablesAndConditionsInList(value, phase, variables,
01283                                           build_file)
01284     elif type(value) is not int:
01285       raise TypeError('Unknown type ' + value.__class__.__name__ + \
01286                       ' for ' + key)
01287 
01288 
01289 def ProcessVariablesAndConditionsInList(the_list, phase, variables,
01290                                         build_file):
01291   # Iterate using an index so that new values can be assigned into the_list.
01292   index = 0
01293   while index < len(the_list):
01294     item = the_list[index]
01295     if type(item) is dict:
01296       # Make a copy of the variables dict so that it won't influence anything
01297       # outside of its own scope.
01298       ProcessVariablesAndConditionsInDict(item, phase, variables, build_file)
01299     elif type(item) is list:
01300       ProcessVariablesAndConditionsInList(item, phase, variables, build_file)
01301     elif type(item) is str:
01302       expanded = ExpandVariables(item, phase, variables, build_file)
01303       if type(expanded) in (str, int):
01304         the_list[index] = expanded
01305       elif type(expanded) is list:
01306         the_list[index:index+1] = expanded
01307         index += len(expanded)
01308 
01309         # index now identifies the next item to examine.  Continue right now
01310         # without falling into the index increment below.
01311         continue
01312       else:
01313         raise ValueError(
01314               'Variable expansion in this context permits strings and ' + \
01315               'lists only, found ' + expanded.__class__.__name__ + ' at ' + \
01316               index)
01317     elif type(item) is not int:
01318       raise TypeError('Unknown type ' + item.__class__.__name__ + \
01319                       ' at index ' + index)
01320     index = index + 1
01321 
01322 
01323 def BuildTargetsDict(data):
01324   """Builds a dict mapping fully-qualified target names to their target dicts.
01325 
01326   |data| is a dict mapping loaded build files by pathname relative to the
01327   current directory.  Values in |data| are build file contents.  For each
01328   |data| value with a "targets" key, the value of the "targets" key is taken
01329   as a list containing target dicts.  Each target's fully-qualified name is
01330   constructed from the pathname of the build file (|data| key) and its
01331   "target_name" property.  These fully-qualified names are used as the keys
01332   in the returned dict.  These keys provide access to the target dicts,
01333   the dicts in the "targets" lists.
01334   """
01335 
01336   targets = {}
01337   for build_file in data['target_build_files']:
01338     for target in data[build_file].get('targets', []):
01339       target_name = gyp.common.QualifiedTarget(build_file,
01340                                                target['target_name'],
01341                                                target['toolset'])
01342       if target_name in targets:
01343         raise GypError('Duplicate target definitions for ' + target_name)
01344       targets[target_name] = target
01345 
01346   return targets
01347 
01348 
01349 def QualifyDependencies(targets):
01350   """Make dependency links fully-qualified relative to the current directory.
01351 
01352   |targets| is a dict mapping fully-qualified target names to their target
01353   dicts.  For each target in this dict, keys known to contain dependency
01354   links are examined, and any dependencies referenced will be rewritten
01355   so that they are fully-qualified and relative to the current directory.
01356   All rewritten dependencies are suitable for use as keys to |targets| or a
01357   similar dict.
01358   """
01359 
01360   all_dependency_sections = [dep + op
01361                              for dep in dependency_sections
01362                              for op in ('', '!', '/')]
01363 
01364   for target, target_dict in targets.iteritems():
01365     target_build_file = gyp.common.BuildFile(target)
01366     toolset = target_dict['toolset']
01367     for dependency_key in all_dependency_sections:
01368       dependencies = target_dict.get(dependency_key, [])
01369       for index in xrange(0, len(dependencies)):
01370         dep_file, dep_target, dep_toolset = gyp.common.ResolveTarget(
01371             target_build_file, dependencies[index], toolset)
01372         if not multiple_toolsets:
01373           # Ignore toolset specification in the dependency if it is specified.
01374           dep_toolset = toolset
01375         dependency = gyp.common.QualifiedTarget(dep_file,
01376                                                 dep_target,
01377                                                 dep_toolset)
01378         dependencies[index] = dependency
01379 
01380         # Make sure anything appearing in a list other than "dependencies" also
01381         # appears in the "dependencies" list.
01382         if dependency_key != 'dependencies' and \
01383            dependency not in target_dict['dependencies']:
01384           raise GypError('Found ' + dependency + ' in ' + dependency_key +
01385                          ' of ' + target + ', but not in dependencies')
01386 
01387 
01388 def ExpandWildcardDependencies(targets, data):
01389   """Expands dependencies specified as build_file:*.
01390 
01391   For each target in |targets|, examines sections containing links to other
01392   targets.  If any such section contains a link of the form build_file:*, it
01393   is taken as a wildcard link, and is expanded to list each target in
01394   build_file.  The |data| dict provides access to build file dicts.
01395 
01396   Any target that does not wish to be included by wildcard can provide an
01397   optional "suppress_wildcard" key in its target dict.  When present and
01398   true, a wildcard dependency link will not include such targets.
01399 
01400   All dependency names, including the keys to |targets| and the values in each
01401   dependency list, must be qualified when this function is called.
01402   """
01403 
01404   for target, target_dict in targets.iteritems():
01405     toolset = target_dict['toolset']
01406     target_build_file = gyp.common.BuildFile(target)
01407     for dependency_key in dependency_sections:
01408       dependencies = target_dict.get(dependency_key, [])
01409 
01410       # Loop this way instead of "for dependency in" or "for index in xrange"
01411       # because the dependencies list will be modified within the loop body.
01412       index = 0
01413       while index < len(dependencies):
01414         (dependency_build_file, dependency_target, dependency_toolset) = \
01415             gyp.common.ParseQualifiedTarget(dependencies[index])
01416         if dependency_target != '*' and dependency_toolset != '*':
01417           # Not a wildcard.  Keep it moving.
01418           index = index + 1
01419           continue
01420 
01421         if dependency_build_file == target_build_file:
01422           # It's an error for a target to depend on all other targets in
01423           # the same file, because a target cannot depend on itself.
01424           raise GypError('Found wildcard in ' + dependency_key + ' of ' +
01425                          target + ' referring to same build file')
01426 
01427         # Take the wildcard out and adjust the index so that the next
01428         # dependency in the list will be processed the next time through the
01429         # loop.
01430         del dependencies[index]
01431         index = index - 1
01432 
01433         # Loop through the targets in the other build file, adding them to
01434         # this target's list of dependencies in place of the removed
01435         # wildcard.
01436         dependency_target_dicts = data[dependency_build_file]['targets']
01437         for dependency_target_dict in dependency_target_dicts:
01438           if int(dependency_target_dict.get('suppress_wildcard', False)):
01439             continue
01440           dependency_target_name = dependency_target_dict['target_name']
01441           if (dependency_target != '*' and
01442               dependency_target != dependency_target_name):
01443             continue
01444           dependency_target_toolset = dependency_target_dict['toolset']
01445           if (dependency_toolset != '*' and
01446               dependency_toolset != dependency_target_toolset):
01447             continue
01448           dependency = gyp.common.QualifiedTarget(dependency_build_file,
01449                                                   dependency_target_name,
01450                                                   dependency_target_toolset)
01451           index = index + 1
01452           dependencies.insert(index, dependency)
01453 
01454         index = index + 1
01455 
01456 
01457 def Unify(l):
01458   """Removes duplicate elements from l, keeping the first element."""
01459   seen = {}
01460   return [seen.setdefault(e, e) for e in l if e not in seen]
01461 
01462 
01463 def RemoveDuplicateDependencies(targets):
01464   """Makes sure every dependency appears only once in all targets's dependency
01465   lists."""
01466   for target_name, target_dict in targets.iteritems():
01467     for dependency_key in dependency_sections:
01468       dependencies = target_dict.get(dependency_key, [])
01469       if dependencies:
01470         target_dict[dependency_key] = Unify(dependencies)
01471 
01472 
01473 def Filter(l, item):
01474   """Removes item from l."""
01475   res = {}
01476   return [res.setdefault(e, e) for e in l if e != item]
01477 
01478 
01479 def RemoveSelfDependencies(targets):
01480   """Remove self dependencies from targets that have the prune_self_dependency
01481   variable set."""
01482   for target_name, target_dict in targets.iteritems():
01483     for dependency_key in dependency_sections:
01484       dependencies = target_dict.get(dependency_key, [])
01485       if dependencies:
01486         for t in dependencies:
01487           if t == target_name:
01488             if targets[t].get('variables', {}).get('prune_self_dependency', 0):
01489               target_dict[dependency_key] = Filter(dependencies, target_name)
01490 
01491 
01492 def RemoveLinkDependenciesFromNoneTargets(targets):
01493   """Remove dependencies having the 'link_dependency' attribute from the 'none'
01494   targets."""
01495   for target_name, target_dict in targets.iteritems():
01496     for dependency_key in dependency_sections:
01497       dependencies = target_dict.get(dependency_key, [])
01498       if dependencies:
01499         for t in dependencies:
01500           if target_dict.get('type', None) == 'none':
01501             if targets[t].get('variables', {}).get('link_dependency', 0):
01502               target_dict[dependency_key] = \
01503                   Filter(target_dict[dependency_key], t)
01504 
01505 
01506 class DependencyGraphNode(object):
01507   """
01508 
01509   Attributes:
01510     ref: A reference to an object that this DependencyGraphNode represents.
01511     dependencies: List of DependencyGraphNodes on which this one depends.
01512     dependents: List of DependencyGraphNodes that depend on this one.
01513   """
01514 
01515   class CircularException(GypError):
01516     pass
01517 
01518   def __init__(self, ref):
01519     self.ref = ref
01520     self.dependencies = []
01521     self.dependents = []
01522 
01523   def __repr__(self):
01524     return '<DependencyGraphNode: %r>' % self.ref
01525 
01526   def FlattenToList(self):
01527     # flat_list is the sorted list of dependencies - actually, the list items
01528     # are the "ref" attributes of DependencyGraphNodes.  Every target will
01529     # appear in flat_list after all of its dependencies, and before all of its
01530     # dependents.
01531     flat_list = OrderedSet()
01532 
01533     # in_degree_zeros is the list of DependencyGraphNodes that have no
01534     # dependencies not in flat_list.  Initially, it is a copy of the children
01535     # of this node, because when the graph was built, nodes with no
01536     # dependencies were made implicit dependents of the root node.
01537     in_degree_zeros = set(self.dependents[:])
01538 
01539     while in_degree_zeros:
01540       # Nodes in in_degree_zeros have no dependencies not in flat_list, so they
01541       # can be appended to flat_list.  Take these nodes out of in_degree_zeros
01542       # as work progresses, so that the next node to process from the list can
01543       # always be accessed at a consistent position.
01544       node = in_degree_zeros.pop()
01545       flat_list.add(node.ref)
01546 
01547       # Look at dependents of the node just added to flat_list.  Some of them
01548       # may now belong in in_degree_zeros.
01549       for node_dependent in node.dependents:
01550         is_in_degree_zero = True
01551         # TODO: We want to check through the
01552         # node_dependent.dependencies list but if it's long and we
01553         # always start at the beginning, then we get O(n^2) behaviour.
01554         for node_dependent_dependency in node_dependent.dependencies:
01555           if not node_dependent_dependency.ref in flat_list:
01556             # The dependent one or more dependencies not in flat_list.  There
01557             # will be more chances to add it to flat_list when examining
01558             # it again as a dependent of those other dependencies, provided
01559             # that there are no cycles.
01560             is_in_degree_zero = False
01561             break
01562 
01563         if is_in_degree_zero:
01564           # All of the dependent's dependencies are already in flat_list.  Add
01565           # it to in_degree_zeros where it will be processed in a future
01566           # iteration of the outer loop.
01567           in_degree_zeros.add(node_dependent)
01568 
01569     return list(flat_list)
01570 
01571   def FindCycles(self):
01572     """
01573     Returns a list of cycles in the graph, where each cycle is its own list.
01574     """
01575     results = []
01576     visited = set()
01577 
01578     def Visit(node, path):
01579       for child in node.dependents:
01580         if child in path:
01581           results.append([child] + path[:path.index(child) + 1])
01582         elif not child in visited:
01583           visited.add(child)
01584           Visit(child, [child] + path)
01585 
01586     visited.add(self)
01587     Visit(self, [self])
01588 
01589     return results
01590 
01591   def DirectDependencies(self, dependencies=None):
01592     """Returns a list of just direct dependencies."""
01593     if dependencies == None:
01594       dependencies = []
01595 
01596     for dependency in self.dependencies:
01597       # Check for None, corresponding to the root node.
01598       if dependency.ref != None and dependency.ref not in dependencies:
01599         dependencies.append(dependency.ref)
01600 
01601     return dependencies
01602 
01603   def _AddImportedDependencies(self, targets, dependencies=None):
01604     """Given a list of direct dependencies, adds indirect dependencies that
01605     other dependencies have declared to export their settings.
01606 
01607     This method does not operate on self.  Rather, it operates on the list
01608     of dependencies in the |dependencies| argument.  For each dependency in
01609     that list, if any declares that it exports the settings of one of its
01610     own dependencies, those dependencies whose settings are "passed through"
01611     are added to the list.  As new items are added to the list, they too will
01612     be processed, so it is possible to import settings through multiple levels
01613     of dependencies.
01614 
01615     This method is not terribly useful on its own, it depends on being
01616     "primed" with a list of direct dependencies such as one provided by
01617     DirectDependencies.  DirectAndImportedDependencies is intended to be the
01618     public entry point.
01619     """
01620 
01621     if dependencies == None:
01622       dependencies = []
01623 
01624     index = 0
01625     while index < len(dependencies):
01626       dependency = dependencies[index]
01627       dependency_dict = targets[dependency]
01628       # Add any dependencies whose settings should be imported to the list
01629       # if not already present.  Newly-added items will be checked for
01630       # their own imports when the list iteration reaches them.
01631       # Rather than simply appending new items, insert them after the
01632       # dependency that exported them.  This is done to more closely match
01633       # the depth-first method used by DeepDependencies.
01634       add_index = 1
01635       for imported_dependency in \
01636           dependency_dict.get('export_dependent_settings', []):
01637         if imported_dependency not in dependencies:
01638           dependencies.insert(index + add_index, imported_dependency)
01639           add_index = add_index + 1
01640       index = index + 1
01641 
01642     return dependencies
01643 
01644   def DirectAndImportedDependencies(self, targets, dependencies=None):
01645     """Returns a list of a target's direct dependencies and all indirect
01646     dependencies that a dependency has advertised settings should be exported
01647     through the dependency for.
01648     """
01649 
01650     dependencies = self.DirectDependencies(dependencies)
01651     return self._AddImportedDependencies(targets, dependencies)
01652 
01653   def DeepDependencies(self, dependencies=None):
01654     """Returns an OrderedSet of all of a target's dependencies, recursively."""
01655     if dependencies is None:
01656       # Using a list to get ordered output and a set to do fast "is it
01657       # already added" checks.
01658       dependencies = OrderedSet()
01659 
01660     for dependency in self.dependencies:
01661       # Check for None, corresponding to the root node.
01662       if dependency.ref is None:
01663         continue
01664       if dependency.ref not in dependencies:
01665         dependencies.add(dependency.ref)
01666         dependency.DeepDependencies(dependencies)
01667 
01668     return dependencies
01669 
01670   def _LinkDependenciesInternal(self, targets, include_shared_libraries,
01671                                 dependencies=None, initial=True):
01672     """Returns an OrderedSet of dependency targets that are linked
01673     into this target.
01674 
01675     This function has a split personality, depending on the setting of
01676     |initial|.  Outside callers should always leave |initial| at its default
01677     setting.
01678 
01679     When adding a target to the list of dependencies, this function will
01680     recurse into itself with |initial| set to False, to collect dependencies
01681     that are linked into the linkable target for which the list is being built.
01682 
01683     If |include_shared_libraries| is False, the resulting dependencies will not
01684     include shared_library targets that are linked into this target.
01685     """
01686     if dependencies is None:
01687       # Using a list to get ordered output and a set to do fast "is it
01688       # already added" checks.
01689       dependencies = OrderedSet()
01690 
01691     # Check for None, corresponding to the root node.
01692     if self.ref is None:
01693       return dependencies
01694 
01695     # It's kind of sucky that |targets| has to be passed into this function,
01696     # but that's presently the easiest way to access the target dicts so that
01697     # this function can find target types.
01698 
01699     if 'target_name' not in targets[self.ref]:
01700       raise GypError("Missing 'target_name' field in target.")
01701 
01702     if 'type' not in targets[self.ref]:
01703       raise GypError("Missing 'type' field in target %s" %
01704                      targets[self.ref]['target_name'])
01705 
01706     target_type = targets[self.ref]['type']
01707 
01708     is_linkable = target_type in linkable_types
01709 
01710     if initial and not is_linkable:
01711       # If this is the first target being examined and it's not linkable,
01712       # return an empty list of link dependencies, because the link
01713       # dependencies are intended to apply to the target itself (initial is
01714       # True) and this target won't be linked.
01715       return dependencies
01716 
01717     # Don't traverse 'none' targets if explicitly excluded.
01718     if (target_type == 'none' and
01719         not targets[self.ref].get('dependencies_traverse', True)):
01720       dependencies.add(self.ref)
01721       return dependencies
01722 
01723     # Executables and loadable modules are already fully and finally linked.
01724     # Nothing else can be a link dependency of them, there can only be
01725     # dependencies in the sense that a dependent target might run an
01726     # executable or load the loadable_module.
01727     if not initial and target_type in ('executable', 'loadable_module'):
01728       return dependencies
01729 
01730     # Shared libraries are already fully linked.  They should only be included
01731     # in |dependencies| when adjusting static library dependencies (in order to
01732     # link against the shared_library's import lib), but should not be included
01733     # in |dependencies| when propagating link_settings.
01734     # The |include_shared_libraries| flag controls which of these two cases we
01735     # are handling.
01736     if (not initial and target_type == 'shared_library' and
01737         not include_shared_libraries):
01738       return dependencies
01739 
01740     # The target is linkable, add it to the list of link dependencies.
01741     if self.ref not in dependencies:
01742       dependencies.add(self.ref)
01743       if initial or not is_linkable:
01744         # If this is a subsequent target and it's linkable, don't look any
01745         # further for linkable dependencies, as they'll already be linked into
01746         # this target linkable.  Always look at dependencies of the initial
01747         # target, and always look at dependencies of non-linkables.
01748         for dependency in self.dependencies:
01749           dependency._LinkDependenciesInternal(targets,
01750                                                include_shared_libraries,
01751                                                dependencies, False)
01752 
01753     return dependencies
01754 
01755   def DependenciesForLinkSettings(self, targets):
01756     """
01757     Returns a list of dependency targets whose link_settings should be merged
01758     into this target.
01759     """
01760 
01761     # TODO(sbaig) Currently, chrome depends on the bug that shared libraries'
01762     # link_settings are propagated.  So for now, we will allow it, unless the
01763     # 'allow_sharedlib_linksettings_propagation' flag is explicitly set to
01764     # False.  Once chrome is fixed, we can remove this flag.
01765     include_shared_libraries = \
01766         targets[self.ref].get('allow_sharedlib_linksettings_propagation', True)
01767     return self._LinkDependenciesInternal(targets, include_shared_libraries)
01768 
01769   def DependenciesToLinkAgainst(self, targets):
01770     """
01771     Returns a list of dependency targets that are linked into this target.
01772     """
01773     return self._LinkDependenciesInternal(targets, True)
01774 
01775 
01776 def BuildDependencyList(targets):
01777   # Create a DependencyGraphNode for each target.  Put it into a dict for easy
01778   # access.
01779   dependency_nodes = {}
01780   for target, spec in targets.iteritems():
01781     if target not in dependency_nodes:
01782       dependency_nodes[target] = DependencyGraphNode(target)
01783 
01784   # Set up the dependency links.  Targets that have no dependencies are treated
01785   # as dependent on root_node.
01786   root_node = DependencyGraphNode(None)
01787   for target, spec in targets.iteritems():
01788     target_node = dependency_nodes[target]
01789     target_build_file = gyp.common.BuildFile(target)
