01790     dependencies = spec.get('dependencies')
01791     if not dependencies:
01792       target_node.dependencies = [root_node]
01793       root_node.dependents.append(target_node)
01794     else:
01795       for dependency in dependencies:
01796         dependency_node = dependency_nodes.get(dependency)
01797         if not dependency_node:
01798           raise GypError("Dependency '%s' not found while "
01799                          "trying to load target %s" % (dependency, target))
01800         target_node.dependencies.append(dependency_node)
01801         dependency_node.dependents.append(target_node)
01802 
01803   flat_list = root_node.FlattenToList()
01804 
01805   # If there's anything left unvisited, there must be a circular dependency
01806   # (cycle).
01807   if len(flat_list) != len(targets):
01808     if not root_node.dependents:
01809       # If all targets have dependencies, add the first target as a dependent
01810       # of root_node so that the cycle can be discovered from root_node.
01811       target = targets.keys()[0]
01812       target_node = dependency_nodes[target]
01813       target_node.dependencies.append(root_node)
01814       root_node.dependents.append(target_node)
01815 
01816     cycles = []
01817     for cycle in root_node.FindCycles():
01818       paths = [node.ref for node in cycle]
01819       cycles.append('Cycle: %s' % ' -> '.join(paths))
01820     raise DependencyGraphNode.CircularException(
01821         'Cycles in dependency graph detected:\n' + '\n'.join(cycles))
01822 
01823   return [dependency_nodes, flat_list]
01824 
01825 
01826 def VerifyNoGYPFileCircularDependencies(targets):
01827   # Create a DependencyGraphNode for each gyp file containing a target.  Put
01828   # it into a dict for easy access.
01829   dependency_nodes = {}
01830   for target in targets.iterkeys():
01831     build_file = gyp.common.BuildFile(target)
01832     if not build_file in dependency_nodes:
01833       dependency_nodes[build_file] = DependencyGraphNode(build_file)
01834 
01835   # Set up the dependency links.
01836   for target, spec in targets.iteritems():
01837     build_file = gyp.common.BuildFile(target)
01838     build_file_node = dependency_nodes[build_file]
01839     target_dependencies = spec.get('dependencies', [])
01840     for dependency in target_dependencies:
01841       try:
01842         dependency_build_file = gyp.common.BuildFile(dependency)
01843       except GypError, e:
01844         gyp.common.ExceptionAppend(
01845             e, 'while computing dependencies of .gyp file %s' % build_file)
01846         raise
01847 
01848       if dependency_build_file == build_file:
01849         # A .gyp file is allowed to refer back to itself.
01850         continue
01851       dependency_node = dependency_nodes.get(dependency_build_file)
01852       if not dependency_node:
01853         raise GypError("Dependancy '%s' not found" % dependency_build_file)
01854       if dependency_node not in build_file_node.dependencies:
01855         build_file_node.dependencies.append(dependency_node)
01856         dependency_node.dependents.append(build_file_node)
01857 
01858 
01859   # Files that have no dependencies are treated as dependent on root_node.
01860   root_node = DependencyGraphNode(None)
01861   for build_file_node in dependency_nodes.itervalues():
01862     if len(build_file_node.dependencies) == 0:
01863       build_file_node.dependencies.append(root_node)
01864       root_node.dependents.append(build_file_node)
01865 
01866   flat_list = root_node.FlattenToList()
01867 
01868   # If there's anything left unvisited, there must be a circular dependency
01869   # (cycle).
01870   if len(flat_list) != len(dependency_nodes):
01871     if not root_node.dependents:
01872       # If all files have dependencies, add the first file as a dependent
01873       # of root_node so that the cycle can be discovered from root_node.
01874       file_node = dependency_nodes.values()[0]
01875       file_node.dependencies.append(root_node)
01876       root_node.dependents.append(file_node)
01877     cycles = []
01878     for cycle in root_node.FindCycles():
01879       paths = [node.ref for node in cycle]
01880       cycles.append('Cycle: %s' % ' -> '.join(paths))
01881     raise DependencyGraphNode.CircularException(
01882         'Cycles in .gyp file dependency graph detected:\n' + '\n'.join(cycles))
01883 
01884 
01885 def DoDependentSettings(key, flat_list, targets, dependency_nodes):
01886   # key should be one of all_dependent_settings, direct_dependent_settings,
01887   # or link_settings.
01888 
01889   for target in flat_list:
01890     target_dict = targets[target]
01891     build_file = gyp.common.BuildFile(target)
01892 
01893     if key == 'all_dependent_settings':
01894       dependencies = dependency_nodes[target].DeepDependencies()
01895     elif key == 'direct_dependent_settings':
01896       dependencies = \
01897           dependency_nodes[target].DirectAndImportedDependencies(targets)
01898     elif key == 'link_settings':
01899       dependencies = \
01900           dependency_nodes[target].DependenciesForLinkSettings(targets)
01901     else:
01902       raise GypError("DoDependentSettings doesn't know how to determine "
01903                       'dependencies for ' + key)
01904 
01905     for dependency in dependencies:
01906       dependency_dict = targets[dependency]
01907       if not key in dependency_dict:
01908         continue
01909       dependency_build_file = gyp.common.BuildFile(dependency)
01910       MergeDicts(target_dict, dependency_dict[key],
01911                  build_file, dependency_build_file)
01912 
01913 
01914 def AdjustStaticLibraryDependencies(flat_list, targets, dependency_nodes,
01915                                     sort_dependencies):
01916   # Recompute target "dependencies" properties.  For each static library
01917   # target, remove "dependencies" entries referring to other static libraries,
01918   # unless the dependency has the "hard_dependency" attribute set.  For each
01919   # linkable target, add a "dependencies" entry referring to all of the
01920   # target's computed list of link dependencies (including static libraries
01921   # if no such entry is already present.
01922   for target in flat_list:
01923     target_dict = targets[target]
01924     target_type = target_dict['type']
01925 
01926     if target_type == 'static_library':
01927       if not 'dependencies' in target_dict:
01928         continue
01929 
01930       target_dict['dependencies_original'] = target_dict.get(
01931           'dependencies', [])[:]
01932 
01933       # A static library should not depend on another static library unless
01934       # the dependency relationship is "hard," which should only be done when
01935       # a dependent relies on some side effect other than just the build
01936       # product, like a rule or action output. Further, if a target has a
01937       # non-hard dependency, but that dependency exports a hard dependency,
01938       # the non-hard dependency can safely be removed, but the exported hard
01939       # dependency must be added to the target to keep the same dependency
01940       # ordering.
01941       dependencies = \
01942           dependency_nodes[target].DirectAndImportedDependencies(targets)
01943       index = 0
01944       while index < len(dependencies):
01945         dependency = dependencies[index]
01946         dependency_dict = targets[dependency]
01947 
01948         # Remove every non-hard static library dependency and remove every
01949         # non-static library dependency that isn't a direct dependency.
01950         if (dependency_dict['type'] == 'static_library' and \
01951             not dependency_dict.get('hard_dependency', False)) or \
01952            (dependency_dict['type'] != 'static_library' and \
01953             not dependency in target_dict['dependencies']):
01954           # Take the dependency out of the list, and don't increment index
01955           # because the next dependency to analyze will shift into the index
01956           # formerly occupied by the one being removed.
01957           del dependencies[index]
01958         else:
01959           index = index + 1
01960 
01961       # Update the dependencies. If the dependencies list is empty, it's not
01962       # needed, so unhook it.
01963       if len(dependencies) > 0:
01964         target_dict['dependencies'] = dependencies
01965       else:
01966         del target_dict['dependencies']
01967 
01968     elif target_type in linkable_types:
01969       # Get a list of dependency targets that should be linked into this
01970       # target.  Add them to the dependencies list if they're not already
01971       # present.
01972 
01973       link_dependencies = \
01974           dependency_nodes[target].DependenciesToLinkAgainst(targets)
01975       for dependency in link_dependencies:
01976         if dependency == target:
01977           continue
01978         if not 'dependencies' in target_dict:
01979           target_dict['dependencies'] = []
01980         if not dependency in target_dict['dependencies']:
01981           target_dict['dependencies'].append(dependency)
01982       # Sort the dependencies list in the order from dependents to dependencies.
01983       # e.g. If A and B depend on C and C depends on D, sort them in A, B, C, D.
01984       # Note: flat_list is already sorted in the order from dependencies to
01985       # dependents.
01986       if sort_dependencies and 'dependencies' in target_dict:
01987         target_dict['dependencies'] = [dep for dep in reversed(flat_list)
01988                                        if dep in target_dict['dependencies']]
01989 
01990 
01991 # Initialize this here to speed up MakePathRelative.
01992 exception_re = re.compile(r'''["']?[-/$<>^]''')
01993 
01994 
01995 def MakePathRelative(to_file, fro_file, item):
01996   # If item is a relative path, it's relative to the build file dict that it's
01997   # coming from.  Fix it up to make it relative to the build file dict that
01998   # it's going into.
01999   # Exception: any |item| that begins with these special characters is
02000   # returned without modification.
02001   #   /   Used when a path is already absolute (shortcut optimization;
02002   #       such paths would be returned as absolute anyway)
02003   #   $   Used for build environment variables
02004   #   -   Used for some build environment flags (such as -lapr-1 in a
02005   #       "libraries" section)
02006   #   <   Used for our own variable and command expansions (see ExpandVariables)
02007   #   >   Used for our own variable and command expansions (see ExpandVariables)
02008   #   ^   Used for our own variable and command expansions (see ExpandVariables)
02009   #
02010   #   "/' Used when a value is quoted.  If these are present, then we
02011   #       check the second character instead.
02012   #
02013   if to_file == fro_file or exception_re.match(item):
02014     return item
02015   else:
02016     # TODO(dglazkov) The backslash/forward-slash replacement at the end is a
02017     # temporary measure. This should really be addressed by keeping all paths
02018     # in POSIX until actual project generation.
02019     ret = os.path.normpath(os.path.join(
02020         gyp.common.RelativePath(os.path.dirname(fro_file),
02021                                 os.path.dirname(to_file)),
02022                                 item)).replace('\\', '/')
02023     if item[-1] == '/':
02024       ret += '/'
02025     return ret
02026 
02027 def MergeLists(to, fro, to_file, fro_file, is_paths=False, append=True):
02028   # Python documentation recommends objects which do not support hash
02029   # set this value to None. Python library objects follow this rule.
02030   is_hashable = lambda val: val.__hash__
02031 
02032   # If x is hashable, returns whether x is in s. Else returns whether x is in l.
02033   def is_in_set_or_list(x, s, l):
02034     if is_hashable(x):
02035       return x in s
02036     return x in l
02037 
02038   prepend_index = 0
02039 
02040   # Make membership testing of hashables in |to| (in particular, strings)
02041   # faster.
02042   hashable_to_set = set(x for x in to if is_hashable(x))
02043   for item in fro:
02044     singleton = False
02045     if type(item) in (str, int):
02046       # The cheap and easy case.
02047       if is_paths:
02048         to_item = MakePathRelative(to_file, fro_file, item)
02049       else:
02050         to_item = item
02051 
02052       if not (type(item) is str and item.startswith('-')):
02053         # Any string that doesn't begin with a "-" is a singleton - it can
02054         # only appear once in a list, to be enforced by the list merge append
02055         # or prepend.
02056         singleton = True
02057     elif type(item) is dict:
02058       # Make a copy of the dictionary, continuing to look for paths to fix.
02059       # The other intelligent aspects of merge processing won't apply because
02060       # item is being merged into an empty dict.
02061       to_item = {}
02062       MergeDicts(to_item, item, to_file, fro_file)
02063     elif type(item) is list:
02064       # Recurse, making a copy of the list.  If the list contains any
02065       # descendant dicts, path fixing will occur.  Note that here, custom
02066       # values for is_paths and append are dropped; those are only to be
02067       # applied to |to| and |fro|, not sublists of |fro|.  append shouldn't
02068       # matter anyway because the new |to_item| list is empty.
02069       to_item = []
02070       MergeLists(to_item, item, to_file, fro_file)
02071     else:
02072       raise TypeError(
02073           'Attempt to merge list item of unsupported type ' + \
02074           item.__class__.__name__)
02075 
02076     if append:
02077       # If appending a singleton that's already in the list, don't append.
02078       # This ensures that the earliest occurrence of the item will stay put.
02079       if not singleton or not is_in_set_or_list(to_item, hashable_to_set, to):
02080         to.append(to_item)
02081         if is_hashable(to_item):
02082           hashable_to_set.add(to_item)
02083     else:
02084       # If prepending a singleton that's already in the list, remove the
02085       # existing instance and proceed with the prepend.  This ensures that the
02086       # item appears at the earliest possible position in the list.
02087       while singleton and to_item in to:
02088         to.remove(to_item)
02089 
02090       # Don't just insert everything at index 0.  That would prepend the new
02091       # items to the list in reverse order, which would be an unwelcome
02092       # surprise.
02093       to.insert(prepend_index, to_item)
02094       if is_hashable(to_item):
02095         hashable_to_set.add(to_item)
02096       prepend_index = prepend_index + 1
02097 
02098 
02099 def MergeDicts(to, fro, to_file, fro_file):
02100   # I wanted to name the parameter "from" but it's a Python keyword...
02101   for k, v in fro.iteritems():
02102     # It would be nice to do "if not k in to: to[k] = v" but that wouldn't give
02103     # copy semantics.  Something else may want to merge from the |fro| dict
02104     # later, and having the same dict ref pointed to twice in the tree isn't
02105     # what anyone wants considering that the dicts may subsequently be
02106     # modified.
02107     if k in to:
02108       bad_merge = False
02109       if type(v) in (str, int):
02110         if type(to[k]) not in (str, int):
02111           bad_merge = True
02112       elif type(v) is not type(to[k]):
02113         bad_merge = True
02114 
02115       if bad_merge:
02116         raise TypeError(
02117             'Attempt to merge dict value of type ' + v.__class__.__name__ + \
02118             ' into incompatible type ' + to[k].__class__.__name__ + \
02119             ' for key ' + k)
02120     if type(v) in (str, int):
02121       # Overwrite the existing value, if any.  Cheap and easy.
02122       is_path = IsPathSection(k)
02123       if is_path:
02124         to[k] = MakePathRelative(to_file, fro_file, v)
02125       else:
02126         to[k] = v
02127     elif type(v) is dict:
02128       # Recurse, guaranteeing copies will be made of objects that require it.
02129       if not k in to:
02130         to[k] = {}
02131       MergeDicts(to[k], v, to_file, fro_file)
02132     elif type(v) is list:
02133       # Lists in dicts can be merged with different policies, depending on
02134       # how the key in the "from" dict (k, the from-key) is written.
02135       #
02136       # If the from-key has          ...the to-list will have this action
02137       # this character appended:...     applied when receiving the from-list:
02138       #                           =  replace
02139       #                           +  prepend
02140       #                           ?  set, only if to-list does not yet exist
02141       #                      (none)  append
02142       #
02143       # This logic is list-specific, but since it relies on the associated
02144       # dict key, it's checked in this dict-oriented function.
02145       ext = k[-1]
02146       append = True
02147       if ext == '=':
02148         list_base = k[:-1]
02149         lists_incompatible = [list_base, list_base + '?']
02150         to[list_base] = []
02151       elif ext == '+':
02152         list_base = k[:-1]
02153         lists_incompatible = [list_base + '=', list_base + '?']
02154         append = False
02155       elif ext == '?':
02156         list_base = k[:-1]
02157         lists_incompatible = [list_base, list_base + '=', list_base + '+']
02158       else:
02159         list_base = k
02160         lists_incompatible = [list_base + '=', list_base + '?']
02161 
02162       # Some combinations of merge policies appearing together are meaningless.
02163       # It's stupid to replace and append simultaneously, for example.  Append
02164       # and prepend are the only policies that can coexist.
02165       for list_incompatible in lists_incompatible:
02166         if list_incompatible in fro:
02167           raise GypError('Incompatible list policies ' + k + ' and ' +
02168                          list_incompatible)
02169 
02170       if list_base in to:
02171         if ext == '?':
02172           # If the key ends in "?", the list will only be merged if it doesn't
02173           # already exist.
02174           continue
02175         elif type(to[list_base]) is not list:
02176           # This may not have been checked above if merging in a list with an
02177           # extension character.
02178           raise TypeError(
02179               'Attempt to merge dict value of type ' + v.__class__.__name__ + \
02180               ' into incompatible type ' + to[list_base].__class__.__name__ + \
02181               ' for key ' + list_base + '(' + k + ')')
02182       else:
02183         to[list_base] = []
02184 
02185       # Call MergeLists, which will make copies of objects that require it.
02186       # MergeLists can recurse back into MergeDicts, although this will be
02187       # to make copies of dicts (with paths fixed), there will be no
02188       # subsequent dict "merging" once entering a list because lists are
02189       # always replaced, appended to, or prepended to.
02190       is_paths = IsPathSection(list_base)
02191       MergeLists(to[list_base], v, to_file, fro_file, is_paths, append)
02192     else:
02193       raise TypeError(
02194           'Attempt to merge dict value of unsupported type ' + \
02195           v.__class__.__name__ + ' for key ' + k)
02196 
02197 
02198 def MergeConfigWithInheritance(new_configuration_dict, build_file,
02199                                target_dict, configuration, visited):
02200   # Skip if previously visted.
02201   if configuration in visited:
02202     return
02203 
02204   # Look at this configuration.
02205   configuration_dict = target_dict['configurations'][configuration]
02206 
02207   # Merge in parents.
02208   for parent in configuration_dict.get('inherit_from', []):
02209     MergeConfigWithInheritance(new_configuration_dict, build_file,
02210                                target_dict, parent, visited + [configuration])
02211 
02212   # Merge it into the new config.
02213   MergeDicts(new_configuration_dict, configuration_dict,
02214              build_file, build_file)
02215 
02216   # Drop abstract.
02217   if 'abstract' in new_configuration_dict:
02218     del new_configuration_dict['abstract']
02219 
02220 
02221 def SetUpConfigurations(target, target_dict):
02222   # key_suffixes is a list of key suffixes that might appear on key names.
02223   # These suffixes are handled in conditional evaluations (for =, +, and ?)
02224   # and rules/exclude processing (for ! and /).  Keys with these suffixes
02225   # should be treated the same as keys without.
02226   key_suffixes = ['=', '+', '?', '!', '/']
02227 
02228   build_file = gyp.common.BuildFile(target)
02229 
02230   # Provide a single configuration by default if none exists.
02231   # TODO(mark): Signal an error if default_configurations exists but
02232   # configurations does not.
02233   if not 'configurations' in target_dict:
02234     target_dict['configurations'] = {'Default': {}}
02235   if not 'default_configuration' in target_dict:
02236     concrete = [i for (i, config) in target_dict['configurations'].iteritems()
02237                 if not config.get('abstract')]
02238     target_dict['default_configuration'] = sorted(concrete)[0]
02239 
02240   merged_configurations = {}
02241   configs = target_dict['configurations']
02242   for (configuration, old_configuration_dict) in configs.iteritems():
02243     # Skip abstract configurations (saves work only).
02244     if old_configuration_dict.get('abstract'):
02245       continue
02246     # Configurations inherit (most) settings from the enclosing target scope.
02247     # Get the inheritance relationship right by making a copy of the target
02248     # dict.
02249     new_configuration_dict = {}
02250     for (key, target_val) in target_dict.iteritems():
02251       key_ext = key[-1:]
02252       if key_ext in key_suffixes:
02253         key_base = key[:-1]
02254       else:
02255         key_base = key
02256       if not key_base in non_configuration_keys:
02257         new_configuration_dict[key] = gyp.simple_copy.deepcopy(target_val)
02258 
02259     # Merge in configuration (with all its parents first).
02260     MergeConfigWithInheritance(new_configuration_dict, build_file,
02261                                target_dict, configuration, [])
02262 
02263     merged_configurations[configuration] = new_configuration_dict
02264 
02265   # Put the new configurations back into the target dict as a configuration.
02266   for configuration in merged_configurations.keys():
02267     target_dict['configurations'][configuration] = (
02268         merged_configurations[configuration])
02269 
02270   # Now drop all the abstract ones.
02271   for configuration in target_dict['configurations'].keys():
02272     old_configuration_dict = target_dict['configurations'][configuration]
02273     if old_configuration_dict.get('abstract'):
02274       del target_dict['configurations'][configuration]
02275 
02276   # Now that all of the target's configurations have been built, go through
02277   # the target dict's keys and remove everything that's been moved into a
02278   # "configurations" section.
02279   delete_keys = []
02280   for key in target_dict:
02281     key_ext = key[-1:]
02282     if key_ext in key_suffixes:
02283       key_base = key[:-1]
02284     else:
02285       key_base = key
02286     if not key_base in non_configuration_keys:
02287       delete_keys.append(key)
02288   for key in delete_keys:
02289     del target_dict[key]
02290 
02291   # Check the configurations to see if they contain invalid keys.
02292   for configuration in target_dict['configurations'].keys():
02293     configuration_dict = target_dict['configurations'][configuration]
02294     for key in configuration_dict.keys():
02295       if key in invalid_configuration_keys:
02296         raise GypError('%s not allowed in the %s configuration, found in '
02297                        'target %s' % (key, configuration, target))
02298 
02299 
02300 
02301 def ProcessListFiltersInDict(name, the_dict):
02302   """Process regular expression and exclusion-based filters on lists.
02303 
02304   An exclusion list is in a dict key named with a trailing "!", like
02305   "sources!".  Every item in such a list is removed from the associated
02306   main list, which in this example, would be "sources".  Removed items are
02307   placed into a "sources_excluded" list in the dict.
02308 
02309   Regular expression (regex) filters are contained in dict keys named with a
02310   trailing "/", such as "sources/" to operate on the "sources" list.  Regex
02311   filters in a dict take the form:
02312     'sources/': [ ['exclude', '_(linux|mac|win)\\.cc$'],
02313                   ['include', '_mac\\.cc$'] ],
02314   The first filter says to exclude all files ending in _linux.cc, _mac.cc, and
02315   _win.cc.  The second filter then includes all files ending in _mac.cc that
02316   are now or were once in the "sources" list.  Items matching an "exclude"
02317   filter are subject to the same processing as would occur if they were listed
02318   by name in an exclusion list (ending in "!").  Items matching an "include"
02319   filter are brought back into the main list if previously excluded by an
02320   exclusion list or exclusion regex filter.  Subsequent matching "exclude"
02321   patterns can still cause items to be excluded after matching an "include".
02322   """
02323 
02324   # Look through the dictionary for any lists whose keys end in "!" or "/".
02325   # These are lists that will be treated as exclude lists and regular
02326   # expression-based exclude/include lists.  Collect the lists that are
02327   # needed first, looking for the lists that they operate on, and assemble
02328   # then into |lists|.  This is done in a separate loop up front, because
02329   # the _included and _excluded keys need to be added to the_dict, and that
02330   # can't be done while iterating through it.
02331 
02332   lists = []
02333   del_lists = []
02334   for key, value in the_dict.iteritems():
02335     operation = key[-1]
02336     if operation != '!' and operation != '/':
02337       continue
02338 
02339     if type(value) is not list:
02340       raise ValueError(name + ' key ' + key + ' must be list, not ' + \
02341                        value.__class__.__name__)
02342 
02343     list_key = key[:-1]
02344     if list_key not in the_dict:
02345       # This happens when there's a list like "sources!" but no corresponding
02346       # "sources" list.  Since there's nothing for it to operate on, queue up
02347       # the "sources!" list for deletion now.
02348       del_lists.append(key)
02349       continue
02350 
02351     if type(the_dict[list_key]) is not list:
02352       value = the_dict[list_key]
02353       raise ValueError(name + ' key ' + list_key + \
02354                        ' must be list, not ' + \
02355                        value.__class__.__name__ + ' when applying ' + \
02356                        {'!': 'exclusion', '/': 'regex'}[operation])
02357 
02358     if not list_key in lists:
02359       lists.append(list_key)
02360 
02361   # Delete the lists that are known to be unneeded at this point.
02362   for del_list in del_lists:
02363     del the_dict[del_list]
02364 
02365   for list_key in lists:
02366     the_list = the_dict[list_key]
02367 
02368     # Initialize the list_actions list, which is parallel to the_list.  Each
02369     # item in list_actions identifies whether the corresponding item in
02370     # the_list should be excluded, unconditionally preserved (included), or
02371     # whether no exclusion or inclusion has been applied.  Items for which
02372     # no exclusion or inclusion has been applied (yet) have value -1, items
02373     # excluded have value 0, and items included have value 1.  Includes and
02374     # excludes override previous actions.  All items in list_actions are
02375     # initialized to -1 because no excludes or includes have been processed
02376     # yet.
02377     list_actions = list((-1,) * len(the_list))
02378 
02379     exclude_key = list_key + '!'
02380     if exclude_key in the_dict:
02381       for exclude_item in the_dict[exclude_key]:
02382         for index in xrange(0, len(the_list)):
02383           if exclude_item == the_list[index]:
02384             # This item matches the exclude_item, so set its action to 0
02385             # (exclude).
02386             list_actions[index] = 0
02387 
02388       # The "whatever!" list is no longer needed, dump it.
02389       del the_dict[exclude_key]
02390 
02391     regex_key = list_key + '/'
02392     if regex_key in the_dict:
02393       for regex_item in the_dict[regex_key]:
02394         [action, pattern] = regex_item
02395         pattern_re = re.compile(pattern)
02396 
02397         if action == 'exclude':
02398           # This item matches an exclude regex, so set its value to 0 (exclude).
02399           action_value = 0
02400         elif action == 'include':
02401           # This item matches an include regex, so set its value to 1 (include).
02402           action_value = 1
02403         else:
02404           # This is an action that doesn't make any sense.
02405           raise ValueError('Unrecognized action ' + action + ' in ' + name + \
02406                            ' key ' + regex_key)
02407 
02408         for index in xrange(0, len(the_list)):
02409           list_item = the_list[index]
02410           if list_actions[index] == action_value:
02411             # Even if the regex matches, nothing will change so continue (regex
02412             # searches are expensive).
02413             continue
02414           if pattern_re.search(list_item):
02415             # Regular expression match.
02416             list_actions[index] = action_value
02417 
02418       # The "whatever/" list is no longer needed, dump it.
02419       del the_dict[regex_key]
02420 
02421     # Add excluded items to the excluded list.
02422     #
02423     # Note that exclude_key ("sources!") is different from excluded_key
02424     # ("sources_excluded").  The exclude_key list is input and it was already
02425     # processed and deleted; the excluded_key list is output and it's about
02426     # to be created.
02427     excluded_key = list_key + '_excluded'
02428     if excluded_key in the_dict:
02429       raise GypError(name + ' key ' + excluded_key +
02430                      ' must not be present prior '
02431                      ' to applying exclusion/regex filters for ' + list_key)
02432 
02433     excluded_list = []
02434 
02435     # Go backwards through the list_actions list so that as items are deleted,
02436     # the indices of items that haven't been seen yet don't shift.  That means
02437     # that things need to be prepended to excluded_list to maintain them in the
02438     # same order that they existed in the_list.
02439     for index in xrange(len(list_actions) - 1, -1, -1):
02440       if list_actions[index] == 0:
02441         # Dump anything with action 0 (exclude).  Keep anything with action 1
02442         # (include) or -1 (no include or exclude seen for the item).
02443         excluded_list.insert(0, the_list[index])
02444         del the_list[index]
02445 
02446     # If anything was excluded, put the excluded list into the_dict at
02447     # excluded_key.
02448     if len(excluded_list) > 0:
02449       the_dict[excluded_key] = excluded_list
02450 
02451   # Now recurse into subdicts and lists that may contain dicts.
02452   for key, value in the_dict.iteritems():
02453     if type(value) is dict:
02454       ProcessListFiltersInDict(key, value)
02455     elif type(value) is list:
02456       ProcessListFiltersInList(key, value)
02457 
02458 
02459 def ProcessListFiltersInList(name, the_list):
02460   for item in the_list:
02461     if type(item) is dict:
02462       ProcessListFiltersInDict(name, item)
02463     elif type(item) is list:
02464       ProcessListFiltersInList(name, item)
02465 
02466 
02467 def ValidateTargetType(target, target_dict):
02468   """Ensures the 'type' field on the target is one of the known types.
02469 
02470   Arguments:
02471     target: string, name of target.
02472     target_dict: dict, target spec.
02473 
02474   Raises an exception on error.
02475   """
02476   VALID_TARGET_TYPES = ('executable', 'loadable_module',
02477                         'static_library', 'shared_library',
02478                         'none')
02479   target_type = target_dict.get('type', None)
02480   if target_type not in VALID_TARGET_TYPES:
02481     raise GypError("Target %s has an invalid target type '%s'.  "
02482                    "Must be one of %s." %
02483                    (target, target_type, '/'.join(VALID_TARGET_TYPES)))
02484   if (target_dict.get('standalone_static_library', 0) and
02485       not target_type == 'static_library'):
02486     raise GypError('Target %s has type %s but standalone_static_library flag is'
02487                    ' only valid for static_library type.' % (target,
02488                                                              target_type))
02489 
02490 
02491 def ValidateRulesInTarget(target, target_dict, extra_sources_for_rules):
02492   """Ensures that the rules sections in target_dict are valid and consistent,
02493   and determines which sources they apply to.
02494 
02495   Arguments:
02496     target: string, name of target.
02497     target_dict: dict, target spec containing "rules" and "sources" lists.
02498     extra_sources_for_rules: a list of keys to scan for rule matches in
02499         addition to 'sources'.
02500   """
02501 
02502   # Dicts to map between values found in rules' 'rule_name' and 'extension'
02503   # keys and the rule dicts themselves.
02504   rule_names = {}
02505   rule_extensions = {}
02506 
02507   rules = target_dict.get('rules', [])
02508   for rule in rules:
02509     # Make sure that there's no conflict among rule names and extensions.
02510     rule_name = rule['rule_name']
02511     if rule_name in rule_names:
02512       raise GypError('rule %s exists in duplicate, target %s' %
02513                      (rule_name, target))
02514     rule_names[rule_name] = rule
02515 
02516     rule_extension = rule['extension']
02517     if rule_extension.startswith('.'):
02518       rule_extension = rule_extension[1:]
02519     if rule_extension in rule_extensions:
02520       raise GypError(('extension %s associated with multiple rules, ' +
02521                       'target %s rules %s and %s') %
02522                      (rule_extension, target,
02523                       rule_extensions[rule_extension]['rule_name'],
02524                       rule_name))
02525     rule_extensions[rule_extension] = rule
02526 
02527     # Make sure rule_sources isn't already there.  It's going to be
02528     # created below if needed.
02529     if 'rule_sources' in rule:
02530       raise GypError(
02531             'rule_sources must not exist in input, target %s rule %s' %
02532             (target, rule_name))
02533 
02534     rule_sources = []
02535     source_keys = ['sources']
02536     source_keys.extend(extra_sources_for_rules)
02537     for source_key in source_keys:
02538       for source in target_dict.get(source_key, []):
02539         (source_root, source_extension) = os.path.splitext(source)
02540         if source_extension.startswith('.'):
02541           source_extension = source_extension[1:]
02542         if source_extension == rule_extension:
02543           rule_sources.append(source)
02544 
02545     if len(rule_sources) > 0:
02546       rule['rule_sources'] = rule_sources
02547 
02548 
02549 def ValidateRunAsInTarget(target, target_dict, build_file):
02550   target_name = target_dict.get('target_name')
02551   run_as = target_dict.get('run_as')
02552   if not run_as:
02553     return
02554   if type(run_as) is not dict:
02555     raise GypError("The 'run_as' in target %s from file %s should be a "
02556                    "dictionary." %
02557                    (target_name, build_file))
02558   action = run_as.get('action')
02559   if not action:
02560     raise GypError("The 'run_as' in target %s from file %s must have an "
02561                    "'action' section." %
02562                    (target_name, build_file))
02563   if type(action) is not list:
02564     raise GypError("The 'action' for 'run_as' in target %s from file %s "
02565                    "must be a list." %
02566                    (target_name, build_file))
02567   working_directory = run_as.get('working_directory')
02568   if working_directory and type(working_directory) is not str:
02569     raise GypError("The 'working_directory' for 'run_as' in target %s "
02570                    "in file %s should be a string." %
02571                    (target_name, build_file))
02572   environment = run_as.get('environment')
02573   if environment and type(environment) is not dict:
02574     raise GypError("The 'environment' for 'run_as' in target %s "
02575                    "in file %s should be a dictionary." %
02576                    (target_name, build_file))
02577 
02578 
02579 def ValidateActionsInTarget(target, target_dict, build_file):
02580   '''Validates the inputs to the actions in a target.'''
02581   target_name = target_dict.get('target_name')
02582   actions = target_dict.get('actions', [])
02583   for action in actions:
02584     action_name = action.get('action_name')
02585     if not action_name:
02586       raise GypError("Anonymous action in target %s.  "
02587                      "An action must have an 'action_name' field." %
02588                      target_name)
02589     inputs = action.get('inputs', None)
02590     if inputs is None:
02591       raise GypError('Action in target %s has no inputs.' % target_name)
02592     action_command = action.get('action')
02593     if action_command and not action_command[0]:
02594       raise GypError("Empty action as command in target %s." % target_name)
02595 
02596 
02597 def TurnIntIntoStrInDict(the_dict):
02598   """Given dict the_dict, recursively converts all integers into strings.
02599   """
02600   # Use items instead of iteritems because there's no need to try to look at
02601   # reinserted keys and their associated values.
02602   for k, v in the_dict.items():
02603     if type(v) is int:
02604       v = str(v)
02605       the_dict[k] = v
02606     elif type(v) is dict:
02607       TurnIntIntoStrInDict(v)
02608     elif type(v) is list:
02609       TurnIntIntoStrInList(v)
02610 
02611     if type(k) is int:
02612       del the_dict[k]
02613       the_dict[str(k)] = v
02614 
02615 
02616 def TurnIntIntoStrInList(the_list):
02617   """Given list the_list, recursively converts all integers into strings.
02618   """
02619   for index in xrange(0, len(the_list)):
02620     item = the_list[index]
02621     if type(item) is int:
02622       the_list[index] = str(item)
02623     elif type(item) is dict:
02624       TurnIntIntoStrInDict(item)
02625     elif type(item) is list:
02626       TurnIntIntoStrInList(item)
02627 
02628 
02629 def PruneUnwantedTargets(targets, flat_list, dependency_nodes, root_targets,
02630                          data):
02631   """Return only the targets that are deep dependencies of |root_targets|."""
02632   qualified_root_targets = []
02633   for target in root_targets:
02634     target = target.strip()
02635     qualified_targets = gyp.common.FindQualifiedTargets(target, flat_list)
02636     if not qualified_targets:
02637       raise GypError("Could not find target %s" % target)
02638     qualified_root_targets.extend(qualified_targets)
02639 
02640   wanted_targets = {}
02641   for target in qualified_root_targets:
02642     wanted_targets[target] = targets[target]
02643     for dependency in dependency_nodes[target].DeepDependencies():
02644       wanted_targets[dependency] = targets[dependency]
02645 
02646   wanted_flat_list = [t for t in flat_list if t in wanted_targets]
02647 
02648   # Prune unwanted targets from each build_file's data dict.
02649   for build_file in data['target_build_files']:
02650     if not 'targets' in data[build_file]:
02651       continue
02652     new_targets = []
02653     for target in data[build_file]['targets']:
02654       qualified_name = gyp.common.QualifiedTarget(build_file,
02655                                                   target['target_name'],
02656                                                   target['toolset'])
02657       if qualified_name in wanted_targets:
02658         new_targets.append(target)
02659     data[build_file]['targets'] = new_targets
02660 
02661   return wanted_targets, wanted_flat_list
02662 
02663 
02664 def VerifyNoCollidingTargets(targets):
02665   """Verify that no two targets in the same directory share the same name.
02666 
02667   Arguments:
02668     targets: A list of targets in the form 'path/to/file.gyp:target_name'.
02669   """
02670   # Keep a dict going from 'subdirectory:target_name' to 'foo.gyp'.
02671   used = {}
02672   for target in targets:
02673     # Separate out 'path/to/file.gyp, 'target_name' from
02674     # 'path/to/file.gyp:target_name'.
02675     path, name = target.rsplit(':', 1)
02676     # Separate out 'path/to', 'file.gyp' from 'path/to/file.gyp'.
02677     subdir, gyp = os.path.split(path)
02678     # Use '.' for the current directory '', so that the error messages make
02679     # more sense.
02680     if not subdir:
02681       subdir = '.'
02682     # Prepare a key like 'path/to:target_name'.
02683     key = subdir + ':' + name
02684     if key in used:
02685       # Complain if this target is already used.
02686       raise GypError('Duplicate target name "%s" in directory "%s" used both '
02687                      'in "%s" and "%s".' % (name, subdir, gyp, used[key]))
02688     used[key] = gyp
02689 
02690 
02691 def SetGeneratorGlobals(generator_input_info):
02692   # Set up path_sections and non_configuration_keys with the default data plus
02693   # the generator-specific data.
02694   global path_sections
02695   path_sections = set(base_path_sections)
02696   path_sections.update(generator_input_info['path_sections'])
02697 
02698   global non_configuration_keys
02699   non_configuration_keys = base_non_configuration_keys[:]
02700   non_configuration_keys.extend(generator_input_info['non_configuration_keys'])
02701 
02702   global multiple_toolsets
02703   multiple_toolsets = generator_input_info[
02704       'generator_supports_multiple_toolsets']
02705 
02706   global generator_filelist_paths
02707   generator_filelist_paths = generator_input_info['generator_filelist_paths']
02708 
02709 
02710 def Load(build_files, variables, includes, depth, generator_input_info, check,
02711          circular_check, parallel, root_targets):
02712   SetGeneratorGlobals(generator_input_info)
02713   # A generator can have other lists (in addition to sources) be processed
02714   # for rules.
02715   extra_sources_for_rules = generator_input_info['extra_sources_for_rules']
02716 
02717   # Load build files.  This loads every target-containing build file into
02718   # the |data| dictionary such that the keys to |data| are build file names,
02719   # and the values are the entire build file contents after "early" or "pre"
02720   # processing has been done and includes have been resolved.
02721   # NOTE: data contains both "target" files (.gyp) and "includes" (.gypi), as
02722   # well as meta-data (e.g. 'included_files' key). 'target_build_files' keeps
02723   # track of the keys corresponding to "target" files.
02724   data = {'target_build_files': set()}
02725   # Normalize paths everywhere.  This is important because paths will be
02726   # used as keys to the data dict and for references between input files.
02727   build_files = set(map(os.path.normpath, build_files))
02728   if parallel:
02729     LoadTargetBuildFilesParallel(build_files, data, variables, includes, depth,
02730                                  check, generator_input_info)
02731   else:
02732     aux_data = {}
02733     for build_file in build_files:
02734       try:
02735         LoadTargetBuildFile(build_file, data, aux_data,
02736                             variables, includes, depth, check, True)
02737       except Exception, e:
02738         gyp.common.ExceptionAppend(e, 'while trying to load %s' % build_file)
02739         raise
02740 
02741   # Build a dict to access each target's subdict by qualified name.
02742   targets = BuildTargetsDict(data)
02743 
02744   # Fully qualify all dependency links.
02745   QualifyDependencies(targets)
02746 
02747   # Remove self-dependencies from targets that have 'prune_self_dependencies'
02748   # set to 1.
02749   RemoveSelfDependencies(targets)
02750 
02751   # Expand dependencies specified as build_file:*.
02752   ExpandWildcardDependencies(targets, data)
02753 
02754   # Remove all dependencies marked as 'link_dependency' from the targets of
02755   # type 'none'.
02756   RemoveLinkDependenciesFromNoneTargets(targets)
02757 
02758   # Apply exclude (!) and regex (/) list filters only for dependency_sections.
02759   for target_name, target_dict in targets.iteritems():
02760     tmp_dict = {}
02761     for key_base in dependency_sections:
02762       for op in ('', '!', '/'):
02763         key = key_base + op
02764         if key in target_dict:
02765           tmp_dict[key] = target_dict[key]
02766           del target_dict[key]
02767     ProcessListFiltersInDict(target_name, tmp_dict)
02768     # Write the results back to |target_dict|.
02769     for key in tmp_dict:
02770       target_dict[key] = tmp_dict[key]
02771 
02772   # Make sure every dependency appears at most once.
02773   RemoveDuplicateDependencies(targets)
02774 
02775   if circular_check:
02776     # Make sure that any targets in a.gyp don't contain dependencies in other
02777     # .gyp files that further depend on a.gyp.
02778     VerifyNoGYPFileCircularDependencies(targets)
02779 
02780   [dependency_nodes, flat_list] = BuildDependencyList(targets)
02781 
02782   if root_targets:
02783     # Remove, from |targets| and |flat_list|, the targets that are not deep
02784     # dependencies of the targets specified in |root_targets|.
02785     targets, flat_list = PruneUnwantedTargets(
02786         targets, flat_list, dependency_nodes, root_targets, data)
02787 
02788   # Check that no two targets in the same directory have the same name.
02789   VerifyNoCollidingTargets(flat_list)
02790 
02791   # Handle dependent settings of various types.
02792   for settings_type in ['all_dependent_settings',
02793                         'direct_dependent_settings',
02794                         'link_settings']:
02795     DoDependentSettings(settings_type, flat_list, targets, dependency_nodes)
02796 
02797     # Take out the dependent settings now that they've been published to all
02798     # of the targets that require them.
02799     for target in flat_list:
02800       if settings_type in targets[target]:
02801         del targets[target][settings_type]
02802 
02803   # Make sure static libraries don't declare dependencies on other static
02804   # libraries, but that linkables depend on all unlinked static libraries
02805   # that they need so that their link steps will be correct.
02806   gii = generator_input_info
02807   if gii['generator_wants_static_library_dependencies_adjusted']:
02808     AdjustStaticLibraryDependencies(flat_list, targets, dependency_nodes,
02809                                     gii['generator_wants_sorted_dependencies'])
02810 
02811   # Apply "post"/"late"/"target" variable expansions and condition evaluations.
02812   for target in flat_list:
02813     target_dict = targets[target]
02814     build_file = gyp.common.BuildFile(target)
02815     ProcessVariablesAndConditionsInDict(
02816         target_dict, PHASE_LATE, variables, build_file)
02817 
02818   # Move everything that can go into a "configurations" section into one.
02819   for target in flat_list:
02820     target_dict = targets[target]
02821     SetUpConfigurations(target, target_dict)
02822 
02823   # Apply exclude (!) and regex (/) list filters.
02824   for target in flat_list:
02825     target_dict = targets[target]
02826     ProcessListFiltersInDict(target, target_dict)
02827 
02828   # Apply "latelate" variable expansions and condition evaluations.
02829   for target in flat_list:
02830     target_dict = targets[target]
02831     build_file = gyp.common.BuildFile(target)
02832     ProcessVariablesAndConditionsInDict(
02833         target_dict, PHASE_LATELATE, variables, build_file)
02834 
02835   # Make sure that the rules make sense, and build up rule_sources lists as
02836   # needed.  Not all generators will need to use the rule_sources lists, but
02837   # some may, and it seems best to build the list in a common spot.
02838   # Also validate actions and run_as elements in targets.
02839   for target in flat_list:
02840     target_dict = targets[target]
02841     build_file = gyp.common.BuildFile(target)
02842     ValidateTargetType(target, target_dict)
02843     ValidateRulesInTarget(target, target_dict, extra_sources_for_rules)
02844     ValidateRunAsInTarget(target, target_dict, build_file)
02845     ValidateActionsInTarget(target, target_dict, build_file)
02846 
02847   # Generators might not expect ints.  Turn them into strs.
02848   TurnIntIntoStrInDict(data)
02849 
02850   # TODO(mark): Return |data| for now because the generator needs a list of
02851   # build files that came in.  In the future, maybe it should just accept
02852   # a list, and not the whole data dict.
02853   return [flat_list, targets, data]
